Title: Dartington March
Text:
Images. Spent time with Mary Fulkerson, teaching and taking classes. Several of our number
[contacters] have studied with Mary, and she has spent time in Contact, though she prefers
her own work as a basis from which to teach. However, the continuing juxtaposition of her
Anatomical Release work and Contact has provoked a headful of thought; her students in Eng-
land and those from Rochester, N.Y. take to Contact with remarkable ease compared to other
groups in the U.S.
This ease of assimilation is of interest. While the students are lying down, crawling, walking or
running, Mary Fulkerson speaks ritually, encouraging greater sensitivity to alignment and efficient
patterns in the body. The manner of presentation tends to by-pass the though~ of the listener.
The listener is preoccupied with moving or relaxing at the time, and the ritualization has a lulling
effect, soothing in tone and timing. The images she provides are simplified anatomical 'cartoons'
of functioning anatomy as opposed to intellectual or visual anatomy. These images describe .sen-
sations - their location in the body and possible directions in which they might move.
The students then assimilate material directly from their own sensations, culled from releasing
unnecessary tension, work, strain.
Mary Fulkerson finds a rare balance of authority and humility which gives fundamental weight
to her voice without usurping the motivation of the student and avoiding their rebellion or
fascination. Nor does her voice question the integrity of the sensations unique to each student.
Their confidence in the process gathers momentum with the growth of awareness of the functional
anatomy, and soon, non-anatomical images can be simply physicalized. Earlier in the process
however, before these channels become clear, an illogical image would more likely provoke bewild-
erment, scorn, or intellectual interest, than movement.
The parallel is with the Contact 'stand': The mind of the listener is encouraged to become a
receiving instrument. Fulkerson's images further provide guidance to sensations which improve
function. The stand in Contact isused to remove the habitual masking of the forces-that-be by
relaxing the listener into states of mind where time, gravity, mass and inertia are apparent, where
balance is seen as subtle movement, and social expectations in partnering can be dropped; it is
possible to talk directly to the body~ and for the listener to listen directly with the body. Each
person can hone and direct real physical sensations into their own most direct & efficient dance.
As Mary Fulkerson is currently presenting her work at Dartingtim College (Devon, England) it
is used as a first step providing the student with a map into private anatomical sensations and
improvements. Great care has been given to the anatomical propriety of the images, because
in this work, the idea each person's mind holds of their body is seen as crucial to the awareness
each develops.
Beyond Mary Fulkerson's work there is a question for the student at Dartington. What to do
with the vocabulary they have sensed and the improvements they find in their use of the body?
Many possibilities exist, and one path, that of Contact, seems quite compatible; moving from
the interior of one's functioning anatomy, to functioning with another. I hope in the coming
years more of us have an opportunity to sample this connection.

Title: A Matter of Delicacy
Text:
In response to Daniel Lepkoff's letter last issue (Number Four/Spring 76), a question:
How removed from the defined Contact classes and concepts should one be and continue to call
the material Contact Improvisation? There are two sectors this question affects: the contactor5,
and the public; that is, students, prospective students, or views of contact - the public image as
it were, by which to some degree Contact Improvisation is defined.
Contact is not a finished thing. Changes in its methodology and its result are expected.
However, the definition it has achieved has been a consistent one, giving a useful continuity to those
new performers who wish to communicate, especially on paper, what they are doing in concerts
and classes. For the students of Contact (of whom there have been many hundreds at this writing)
it seems only fair to either follow procedures designed to aid them in dancing with community of
contactors at large, or to indicate in titles and descriptions of classes (as Mangrove has done) the
bridge between Contact Improvisation and new attitudes stemming from Contact, that are actually
quite different in practice. The delicacy comes here: How wide is the definition of Contact to be,
and is Contact well used by this extrapolation? An extreme position relative to the established core
of Contact Improvisation should probably be given another name or reserved for advanced contactors
to whom the references would be clear.
This is a century of extrapolation. It is not coincidental that industrial revolution, the
modern arts, the increased pace of communication and travel have all occurred this past 100 years.
Change of attitude, environment, ideas, reality, happen far more easily now and the problem is
this, change is cheap. Definition has become difficult to establish or to maintain.
The artist has a duty/right to manipulate the techniques which contribute to their art.
There are however, responsibilities to these techniques to keep them clear of confusion. For those
dancers already familiar with Contact techniques, it may be that outside the Contact framework more
improvisational adventure may be found. Should it, however, be called Contact? The dilution or the
refinement of that central experience depends on the consideration_ we give its presentation.

Title: Preface
Text:
It is Contact Improvisation's 25th anniversary this year, an occasion to celebrate and
reflect on Contact Improvisation as a dance form and its growth from a week of performances at
the John Weber Gallery in NYC in June of 1972 initiated by Steve Paxton with a group of young
dancers, to a movement form practiced by thousands of people all over the world. It has been a
remarkable evolution, much of it chronicled in the pages of Contact Quarterly.
In 1975, a few years into the work, we began hearing of physical injuries resulting from
people doing Contact from having seen it in performance, without an introduction to the subtle ·
sensing work that underlies the more vigorous physical activity. How to keep the work safe? we
wondered. Steve, and the small group continuing to practice and show the work with him, con-
sidered trademarking the name and certifying or authorizing teachers. Preliminary papers were
drawn up but were never signed. The prospect of policing Contact was not appealing. More
interesting was the idea of creating a vehicle for communication, a newsletter, in which to report
activity and current thinking within the work, in this way keeping the work open, and inviting
ourselves and others further into the dialogue.
This seems to have been a crucial decision, one leading to the considerable expansion of
the work and its enrichment by many individuals over the years.
For the First European Contact Teachers Conference, in Holland in 1985, Margot Rijven,
Karen Nelson, and I manufactured a quick, xeroxed compendium of writings on Contact Improv-
isation from all the issues of Contact Quarterly dance journal that we could get our hands on in
Amsterdam, including several of the early issues. It was a handy, fascinating volume which we
reprinted twice for the Contact Teachers Conferences at the Breitenbush Hot Springs Contact Jams
in Oregon in 1986 and 1987. We sold the leftover copies through CQ and that was the end of it.
In honor of Contact's silver jubilee, and because many of our early issues are now out of
print, CQ has produced this new and updated, limited edition CI Sourcebook. In it you'll find
the majority of writings on Contact Improvisation that have appeared in CQ from its inception
as Contact Newsletter in 1975 through Volume 17, 1992. CQ issues from 1993 to the present,
containing increasing amounts of Contact dialogue, are available through CQ as back issues.
The making of the CQ/CI Sourcebook was a big job, bigger than any of us expected.
Each page has been carefully prepared by Harriett Jastremsky and Mette Gustavsen, photocopied
directly from the original magazine pages with minor alterations, adding volume and year
citations at the bottom of each page to orient you. They handled all aspects of the increasingly
complex production with grace, curiosity, creativity and good humor.
Some explanation about the recurring section headings in the book: "Definitions" were a
regular feature in the first years of CQ. We included a different definition of Contact in every issue
along with a photo, in this way hoping to record the variety of styles used for presenting/describ-
ing this new movement form as it developed; many are included here. As CQ grew, several
"departments" were created in the magazine to support the increasing exchange amongst Contact
practitioners. "Round Up: CI in perspective" ran from 1976 to 1981 and included a variety of
reviews and views of the work. In 1984 we instituted "Still Moving: Contact shoptalk and
dialogue," to encourage in-depth discussions of the working process that went beyond the newsy
reports in the Contact Newsletter section of the magazine. This column has continued to grow
in substance and in size over the years.
The CQ/C/ Sourcebook contains lively and personal evidence of the growth of Contact
Improvisation as a duet movement form, the community that grew up around it, and the concur-
rent evolution of the magazine. Evidence of people taking initiative to make events happen and
attempting, in many forms, to articulate their findings. Reading through these years of CQ writ-
ings is like going on an archeological dig, into the heart and mind of the work as it lives in the
people who do it. It is satisfying to have these pages together in a single volume. The spirit of
discovery and exchange is strong; the reflection, dimensional.
We hope you find the Sourcebook a useful and enjoyable addition to your library. Your
responses, as well as your own Contact writings, are always welcome at CQ's mailbox. Please
don't hesitate to be in touch.

Title: Interview with Steve Paxton
Text:
ELIZABETI-1: At the very beginning of a Contact Improvisation workshop,
teachers often talk about the 'small dance'. Why do _YOU start
with the 'small dance'?
STEVE: Well, first of all, it's a fairly easy perception: all you have to do
is stand up and then relax-you know-and at a certain point you real-
ize that you've relaxed everything that you can relax but you're still
standing and in that standing is quite a lot of minute movement: .. the
skeleton holding you upright even though you 're mentally relaxing.
Now in that very fact of you ordering yourself to relax and yet continuing
to stand-finding that limit to which you could no further relax without
falling down; you 're put in touch with a basic sustaining effort that goes
on constantly in the body, that you don't have to be aware of. It's
background movement static-you know-that you blot out with your
more interesting activities, yet it's always there sustaining you. We 're
trying to get in touch with these kinds of primal forces in the body and
make them readily apparent. Call it the 'small dance' ... It was a name
chosen largely because it's quite descriptive of the situation and because
while you 're doing the stand and feeling the 'small dance' you 're aware
that you 're not 'doing' it, so, in a way, you 're watching yourself perform;
watching your body perform its function. And your mind is not figuring
anything out and not searching for anv answers or being used as an
active instrument but is being used as a lens to focus on certain
perceptions. DC

Title: A Short History
Text:
It's easy after teaching awhile to forget the beginning, to forget how to share the first steps
of an idea or experience. Remember learning how to walk? It was a logical organic progres-
sion. The body was the teacher. It knew just how to prepare for the next step-it wriggled
and squirmed to get ready to roll, rolled to get ready to creep, creeping became crawling,
crawling prepared for sitting, squatting to standing to falling to standing to stepping to fall-
ing to walking. Watch babies. They have much to teach about how to teach and learn.
In teaching/learning contact improvisation, what are the first steps? What are the basic ex-
periences needed for the next step and the next? Perhaps it would be helpful to remember,
to retrace, the first year of contact improvisation.
What is the last thing you learned?
Can you remember learning it?
How did it happen?
Teaching should reflect the learning process. And learning mirrors the breathing rhythm.

Title: Nijinsky, Rockets, Platform Shoes ...
Text:
I learn from knowing I am uncomfortable, and going ahead; and the
going ahead being the letting-go-ahead. So the discomfort is to be appreciated.
It is an environment from which springs an opening. Contact embraces this
fear of itself. this seminal verge.
We are concerned with where the dancing originates. At times it
appears to me that the important thing is not the dancing in the center of the
circle. but the experience on the edge of the circle, the often disquieting
dance on the verge. This view, which might be seen as antithetical to the
work. is also necessarily part of its premise. The invitation to feel the dread of
opening is an inherent part of the total occurrence.
Dances in which both bodies ride a shared wave of truly unleashed
rise and falling are rare. Yet the dances which abound - halting, starting
repeatedly, responding to impulses a fraction of a second too slow to flow,
doubting one's perceptions - are rich with valuable information, honest
manifestation of fluctuation between positive and negative response. We
fear surrender. make our homes in the almost, and venture into readiness
only when we must. The discomfort at the verge serves by intensifying the
contrast: the darks get darker, the lights lighter, and the picture gets easier
to see.
I value this work not only for the rare glimpses of in-touch, in-time,
in-tune. but for the companionship of the ever-present indications of what is
possible. The form itself, if one exists beyond the instances of attempts to
experience it. is none other than the existence of the possibility of a dance in
which wills. instincts. and verges merge. Emergency, emerge, merge. It
amounts to having to believe in a possibility which one may never have .
experienced.
All this to say I am devoted to something which I rarely feel, the
possibility of which I never leave. We extend to ourselves an invitation which
we rarely accept. but the extension of it is what matters. Living for so long on
the verge of that acceptance, I figure it's time to call it home. o0

Title: Editor Letter
Text:
For the last month I've been going down to
Wesleyan University on Fridays to teach two l '12 hour
classes in Contact Improvisation. Though I've been liking
the students a great deal, I've been grumbling a lot during
the week about the classes being too short. But now the
grumbling is bothering me more than the shortness of the
classes, so it's time to look into the whole ordeal.
The whole ordeal is about time, not enough of it, or
more specifically, not enough of a certain kind of it.
When I teach beginning Contact Improvisation, there
are a few principles I come back to over and over-some
for safety reasons, others for flavor. Some have to do with
expanding one's orientation to space-experiencing space
as spherical, dealing with disorientation, being able to fall,
roll, and ride momentum, alone and in physical contact
with another mover. I suppose this could be called spatial
conditioning.
Then there's time conditioning, which I'm just beginning
to take particular notice of. A lot of the meditations on
physical sensation (e.g. Paxton's "small dance") that have
always been a part of Contact training are actually as much
about inducing an experience of expanded time as they are
about the physical sensations they point up.
This sense of expanded time is a subjective state, one
where time feels mutable and there are slippages-where a
45 minute dance can feel like 5 minutes, while a 2 second
fall can feel luxuriously long. It is a relaxed state, one
where time seems to have been released from its inexorable
unit-to-unit march and allowed to roam in an open field
with wide horizons and no fences, a time whose divisions
and textures vary according to the moods and perceptions
of the people moving through it.
As with spatial training, this new temporal experience
may be puzzling at first. All too often you lose your place
in the dancing, but you find out through experience that
if you just hang on a few seconds longer (those seconds feel
like hours!) your place will come floating up under you like
a pair of lost footprints. You come to trust and in fact look
forward to those gaps because in them you 're as vulnerable
and available as you can be, and from there come new per-
ceptions and some of the more surprising and refreshing
movement material.
But how do we get there from here? Especially when
we 're coming in to the studio from Chemistry or Shakes-
peare or Ballet or a 65 mile drive.
The transition from clock time to internal time can
begin during the personal warmup-a period of time often
given at the beginning of class to relax and "arrive," to get
ready physically and mentally to dance with others. It
deepens during the periods of extended duet improvising.
Absorption in the moment expands the feeling of time and
you come out of it enlivened no matter where you've been.
It's this state of absorption and enlivening that I aim for in
my own dancing and teaching.
I spent the first few weeks at Wesleyan searching in vain
for a quick passage, a trap door into this state. But how
could I hope to transmit the spaciousness, mutability, and
mystery of time when I myself was rushing to get in as much
dancing, skills, improvising, sensitizing, etc. as possible in
the 'short' time available?
Exhausted from my struggle with time, I gave up and
found that simply by relaxing I created more time. It felt
like practicing Aikido, where one redirects an opposing
force by first blending with it, not resisting it. Meanwhile,
of course, as I was internally wrestling with all this, the
students were rolling, giggling, getting dizzy, getting strong,
confused, inspired, thinking it was silly, feeling it was
profound and in general doing Contact Improvisation. As
has often been said, the dancing teaches itself, if the teacher
can only get out of the way long enough to let everyone
dance ....
P.S. After all this, I still think an hour and a half is too
short for a Contact class!

Title: Editor's Report: High Moon -
Text:
The image I had for the last issue (Winter 1976) was the water hole. The
place where we collect to drink. A circle where everyone who comes fits
in. All those cows bent to the water, the lines of their backs, helped me
re-invent the wheel. At the watering hole we stood in order to bring our
weight down; our weight brought the water up. We came full circle.
This time we started again with nothing. New moon. We collected ourselves.
As the last light left, we arranged ourselves in a blind configuration; (blackout
on stage, the lights come up and the performers arc all in place). We started.
Then the crescent moon - we seemed to use the light as it grew, filling in the
implied circle. Journal entry, March 24: " ... Musing new directions, transition
at its most spread out point, as entropy of possibilities peaks." The moon, a new
image to fill, and we, in as much detail as possible, articulate the filling.
Learning the ropes means knowing how far they can take you; how much weight
they can hold. One day, the arc of the rope's swing is predictable and suddenly
short. There is another side; the side just outside your reach. But is your reach
the rope's, or, if you can find a vehicle with a larger range should you ride it. "Lim-
its are what any of us are inside of," Charles Olson said in a talk that was recorded.
In ReUnion's Contact classes we often talk during the warm up. Not necessarily to
suggest specific activities, exercises or structures, but to create an environment, to
supply images that may call out a particular awareness. We talk to the body as
it experiences sensation. We say, "You know that place when you stretch, the
place where the muscle has eased out to its limit, that place on the edge of
stress, on the edge of pain." We say, "Work there, spend some time there,
on this side of the edge." "The edge is home," Lee Breuer said during a
radio interview in Washington, D.C. in 1975. But it seems the edge is
moveable - that by sensing the limit, respecting it, you encourage it
to open. A push comes to a shove. But if you go only as far as you
are welcome, you are invited back.
What has this got to do with the Contact Quarterly. Not sure,
only that I sat down to present the image I was having for
this process. How we stand. How we stand still, and
keep moving.
Palm Sunday. Full Moon. Lunar Eclipse.
NANCY'S FIST & WRIST
LISA'S ErnOW

Title: Contact Improvisation - A Statement of Appreciation
Text:
Contact Improvisation is a dance form that uses movement, gravity and their relationship to each other as revealed through changing points of balance. It is a dance that is neither in balance nor over the edge. It is a dance that is not predetermined, a dance where the dancers disappear and there is only the dance. It is a dance that is accessible to all, regardless of one's physical abilities. It is a dance that is a metaphor for our lives and that has therapeutic value. It is a dance that has spiritual elements, where we contact, or more likely what contacts us during those dances that are out of our constraint, where a third body is created.

Contact Improvisation is a dance that is sheltered under the aegis, the protection, of the founders' predilection for not creating certifications, degrees, professional associations and strict definitions of the form. It is a dance that creates imagery from a broad variety of sources, explores related disciplines, expresses points of view, but ultimately dismisses absolutes. It is a dance that at its best is fluid, and how easy it would be to concretize into a set of exercises and rules this protean dance form.

Contact Improvisation is a dance that is like Rumi's poetry, limenal. It is a dance that expresses the dances that are not predetermined, those rare moments when the dancers disappear and there is only the dance.

Title: A Look Back and a Look Forward
Text:
The work I have done in Contact Improvisation has, needless to say, had a powerful eff~ct in my
life. In the late spring of 1972 Steve told me of a piece he wanted to do in N.Y.C., and I went down
there to rehearse and perform a dance called Contact Improvisation. The work that was done for that
performance and subsequent gatherings for intense periods of dancing was larger and affected more
levels of my being than I was aware of at the time. Most forceably I was struck by the simple yet over-
whelming experience of communion with another person achieved through the dancing, and the freedom
as well as discipline found within that communi~n. I remember feeling literally transported to another
world when dancing, a world in which I was able to become a stronger self than I lived with day to day.
I don't think, in that first performance, anyone fully realized the power of the forces brought into play
among us. Many injuries, pulled, sore, and knotted muscles were the physical result of irresponsibility
in the face of those forces. I became impressed with a sense of responsibility to myself and those I was
dancing with to create a healthy interaction.
The work done during that concert became not something I could forget. The realm of Contact
Improvisation I realized was not "dance" but living, the forces at play between two people dancing are
those forces which exist day to day, the strong self I had experienced was nothing but myself. I was left
with the ever present challenge to realize my strong self in day to day living as well as the responsibility
of achieving a healthy and true communion with those people I meet day to day. I suppose this task
is universal for all living beings, however I have received a lot of strength and focused energy specifically
from the work I have done with Contact Improvisation.
I realize now that in order to continue this work I must be involved in the process of transmission.
lt'seems that with understanding and experience of the forces at play in Contact Improvisation, receiving
becomes transmitting, student becomes teacher, dancing becomes giving. It seems very natural, and I
do not hesitate to think that any one who has had enough experience with Contact will feel this shift of
role. It is no wonder there are now many teachers of Contact Improvisation.
The dancing is just beginning to expand on a social level, into our society. What will be the direction
of this expansion? Contact was created in the context of the dance art world. This is a good place, how-
ever the traditions of possession and ownership among artists are unhealthy for Contact Improvisation.
My dream is that Contact will grow to become a social function. Periodically people living in the same
area will gather for a day or week of dancing, for the sole function of communally reinforcing and acknow-
ledging the strong self inside each person in the face of those one lives with. Walking down the street and
greeting someone, buying groceries in a store, and all the daily interactions of people will be on a truer
more realistic footing, and a general climate of health may be achieved. This may seem far fetched but
I feel the beginning is at hand and in view of this direction it is obvious that we need to:
continue dancing and deepening our experience and familiarity with
the forces at play in Contact Improvisation
keep lines of communication open, i.e. this newsletter,
and cooperatively give and share the experiences and
information gleaned from dancing and teaching.
The class I tried to start in Bennington this summer did not work out. I am trying again this fall
to get some people together to dance. I think I will be picking apples this fall. The seasons are changing
here, color on the trees and colder nights and shorter days, new feelings emerge and don't fit comfortably
yet. Hope to see some of you again, maybe hit the west coast again this year.
Hello to All

Title: Bodies in Contact
Text:
This piece was written in 1979. We
discovered it in our files and found the
issues in it still very much alive. We
talked with Paul about it and be agreed.
He also noted that shortly after this
period, performances of improvisation
in New York City seemed to disappear
for several years. [Eds.]

I suspect there are many
people presently involved in moving
art forms who, except for exposure to
contact improvisation, would not have
entered the field. My experience is a
case in point. As an art major in col-
lege, I enjoyed creating large sculptural
environments for the body. The
weight and awkwardness of the mater-
ials, plywood, two-by-fours, and other
construction hardware, turned building
a piece into a physical work-out.
Sculpting was an arranging dance,
using the whole body.
During this time (1973), Curt Sid-
dall, Nita Little, Steve Paxton, Nancy
Stark Smith, and someone whom I re-
member well except for her name
[Karen Radler] came to perform and
teach contact on the west coast for
the first time. I danced some and
watched a lot. The idea of people
presenting natural movement as a
performance was a pleasant jolt to me.
The democratic give and take between
partners was appealing. Improvising
dance, creating while performing was,
for me, a revelation. And my person-
ality was more comfortable with the
social circumstances of dancing than
the solitude of sculpture.
My first dancing was suffused with
comparisons between sculpture and
contact. It was as if the four-by-eight
plywood sheets I had been building
with developed power steering, and
could even lift me off the ground.
The three-dimensional experience of
sculpture became four-dimensional,
the fourth dimension being the time
of the dance. I was no longer the
manipulator. For every impulse of
mine, there was another independent
nervous system deciding what was hap-
pening as well. I saw that contact is
very purely about process. In terms
of sculpture, that meant showing how
fascinating it is to make a piece, rather
than showing a finished piece.
Through performing, I like letting
others in on the creating side of the
work, the side most interesting to me.
Since that time, I've performed in
many different situations; contact,
other improvised structures, and set
pieces. In watching dance or perform-
ing it, I'm drawn to dancing which
doesn't impose a style on the people
who dance. This may partly be a
hangover from art training which en-
courages students to find an individual
vision from the start of training. I'm
glad this idea has a lot of credence in
the dance world now.
Improvisation is one way of work-
ing individualistically either in a group
or solo. A problem is that improvisa-
tion and performance are sometimes
friends. We all know of our on nights
and our off nights. Those who perform
improvisation have decided that the
pluses outweigh the minuses. The
pluses are that the dancers are present-
ing a raw slice of life, uncut, uncooked.
The audience's position is elevated be-
cause they are allowed to get in on the
whole story as it happens for the first
time. They aren't watching something
which has been edited in rehearsal.
Improvisation is risky and often re-
warding for the performers. It is a way
for performers to move on with work,
not to stick with an image or sequence

Only that Picassos were rather awful and the others were not.
Sure, she said, as Pablo once remarked, when you make a thing,

which must be repeated several times.
The formal qualities of contact make
it a focused and grounded improvisa-
tional technique. There is a basic
agreement between performers which
provides a continual springboard into
the dance. A performer of contact has
a lot of freedom.
I'm sitting here writing about how
good a performance improvisation
makes, and resisting tooth and nail the
detractions. However, there are some.
There is no overall structure to control
the impact of the performance. It's
like having several small dances linked
together. Dull repetition can be a
problem. When this happens, it's like
watching the same rehearsed dance
several times in one piece. This is one
of the main limitations in previous
dance work which many of us are try-
ing to avoid by investigating improvi-
sation. An ideal piece has few seams
showing. There are a lot of ways to
approach this, but they mostly have to
do with pre-planning. It's difficult to
achieve in an improvised performance.
There also are some beautiful possibili-
ties in pre-setting a piece; it can have
long sections of synchronized move-
ment, it can be a story, it can have
special timing, or it can deal with the
personae and not the personality of
the performer. The search for these
qualities is improvised but their presen-
tation is, for the most part, set.
Safety is important in contact.
This results in contact being playful,
game-like, and positive. There is a
utopian communal quality to contact-
a great experience but not the whole
picture. This one-keyed quality can be
limiting for an audience, and make
performing frustrating. There is little
room to explore subjects like discord,
tragedy, or events which are fantastic
or grotesque. Sometimes I want to
entertain/be entertained with these
rich images. Sometimes I want the
purity and abstraction of contact.
When I perform contact, I like to
feel that we, the performers, are shar-
ing the performance with the audience.
Among the most satisfying perform-
ances in this respect was a series done
at the Paula Cooper Gallery in New
York City [1978). We performed in
the afternoon for three days, three
hours per day. The audience was free
to come and go. Those who stayed
wanted to be there. As the perform-

of the audience increased. Neither the
audience nor the piece was set. There
was a cumulative effect from perform-
ing for a long time for three days in a
row. Our dancing became very sure,
and many audience members returned
two or three times to watch. By the
end of the third day we all felt like
good friends. We felt like the home
team.
In the last year, I've been doing
contact wearing different costumes.
The costumes put a context into the
dancing. Nina Martin and I did cos-
tumed contact as part of a living sculp-
ture exhibit at the Susan Caldwell
Gallery. Every half-hour or so, we
changed clothes. We danced in paja-
mas, swimming suits, winter clothes,
formal attire, and disco polyester. The
costumes interest me because they
provide a lasting image, however weird,
of what the dancing is about. A sub-
liminal story unfolded with each
change. (Paul and Nina went to the
prom all dressed up. They felt good

Title: Seen from the Outside
Text:
In ordinary, every-day situations, to make contact
there have to be two. That seems a commonplace
and we simply take it for granted. Watching Con-
tact Improvisation, however, is a strange experience
at first. The making, keeping, and stretching of
contact, there, does not easily fit the accustomed
conceptual schema. It takes quite a while to discov-
er the reason: Its contacts involve not two but four.
In the world of our experience, what we call our "self"
is no more and no less than what we experience of our-
selves. In terms of our senses, our "self" is composed of
what we perceive of ourselves, visually and tactually for the
most part, plus what we internally sense about the states of
, our muscles and organs. This "self" is necessarily very different
from what we are in the experiential world of another person who,
visually and tactually, experiences us from a wholly different point of
view. In Contact Improvisation, therefore, there are two selves, each striving to maintain
contact with another person. Both are constantly the acting subject of their own actions, and at
the same time they are the object of the other's actions. And since the possibilities of making
and maintaining contact are nearly always many, the coordination of motion of the one
dancer that perceives the other and the other that perceives the one, is threatened
at every moment. There is a perpetual struggle to neutralize inherent discrepan-
cies and to preserve a reciprocally invariant relationship of contact. Seen from
the outside, this becomes a powerful and at times shattering allegory of the
precariousness of any harmony in human relations.
If this is not too idiosyncratic an interpretation, it must raise the question:
Will Contact Improvisation really remain a moment-to-moment improv-
isation or will it gradually develop regularities, fixed sequences, and
rules? Contact of two independent agents can be maintained only to
the extent to which one can foresee the motions of the other. (That
goes for ALL relationships, and that is why we always need some
rules and conventions). To IMPROVE in the art of Contact Improv-
isation (or in the art of relating to others) may mean to get better at
predicting the· other's moves AS WELL AS to get better at doing
what 'he orhe-r ex pee.rs.

Title: Teaching Contact Improvisation
Text:
In Banyoles, Spain, two hours north of Barcelona,
there is a 16th-century stone farmhouse with a horsebarn
made into a spacious dance studio. Three large windows
open directly onto manure-rich hay fields. It's harvest time
and the old Spanish farmers throw the bales one by one
onto simple wooden carts pulled by old-model tractors.
The first night of our workshop we meet only briefly in
the studio. In the evening's waning light, we 'arrive'-from
Denmark, Germany, America, Switzerland-we stretch and
breathe, arriving f;om the road, arriving into our bodies,
into the room, smelling the fields, hearing the pigs squeal
and sing altogether in their pens, feeding, down the road.
Without much plan, we dance in the deepening blue light
that obscures faces but leaves a rich glow that's inviting to
dance in. We stand back from the windows, putting what's
left of the light in front of us, and dance and watch each
other in silence. I like this beginning very much. It's un-
adorned and mysterious. Spacious and intimate. We're
ready already. It's nice here.
Two weeks later. A lot has happened. As usual with an
intensive workshop, it's been intense. We seem to have
risked a lot, been satisfied and confused, tired and exuber-
ant, alone and together here by the ripe fig tree in northern
Spain, and now it's time to go. Some don't want to leave,
others are ready, curious to see what new directions these
weeks will produce in their work. Soon the goodbye com-
mittee, waving the others off, whittles down to a solitary
few. Bill and I decide to stay at Arlequi for an extra day,
to not rush leaving, and-very unusual for me-to stay not
only to the end, but after the end.
I found Bill in the studio after everyone was gone, sitting
in the windowframe watching the farmer turning over his
field in the evening light. A brush fire was burning up on
the hill, and it all seemed very still. The light was just as it
had been the first night we came-blueblack, highlighting
surfaces. The room looks small, and so empty, I thought.
How incredible that so much can happen in a place and it
stays empty when you go. That you can fill it so full and
leave and it's still empty.
What I mean is, Yolanda cried out when we changed from
fire to earth state and Ole held onto her until her writhing
passed. She was Spanish, he was Danish, and ... days later
Ole crashed heads with his friend J orgen, both rushing out
of the studio dazed and confused and coming back in later
laughing. And Marie, living through the special dance she
tells of in this issue's "Still Moving" column. I guess it's
really so obvious, especially to dancers, that so much can
grow out of thin air-that just a bunch of people moving
and thinking and talking and seeing can generate such ap-
parent substance and then be gone without a trace.
The ending continued. As soon as we waved the last
person off at the bus, the weather changed dramatically. It
rained all the next day as it hadn't the whole two weeks we
were there. New tenants arrived, invisibly dividing the
house into theirs and ours. It was as if some Red Sea that
had parted now closed over, making the clearing we had
lived in for two weeks not just changed but completely
gone. The figs were still there, ripe and heavy in their
teardrop sacs hanging from the tree. You could run your
fingernail down the side of the soft thick brown mottled
skin, open the fig and find deep red fruit moist and
delicious, so satisfying, so perfect after dancing.

Title: Contact Improvisation: A Defmition
Text:
Contact improvisation is a move-
ment technique. Though much young-
er than ballet or modern dance, it
proves to be as rich and dee~. It ei_n-
bodies a progression of physical skills
which can be used to train the begin-
ner as well as challenge the virtuoso.
Students of contact improvisation
acquire access to a large realm of
movement very quickly and begm to
make significant changes in their
movement patterns, strength, and sen-
sitivity within three or four classes.
This makes the technique particularly
desirable for the theater student and
non-dancer.

The skills acquired in contact im-
provisation are by no means limited
to the form itself. A deep understand-
ing of weight, movement flow, and use
of strength greatly aid anybody who
desires to study ballet, modern dance,
or other physical disciplines. The ex-
tensive exposure to the physical and
mental states involved in improvising
and discovering movement can help
choreographers in their attempts to
gather material for their set work.
Contact improvisation directly
strengthens one's presence. Just as
one can become aware of the eyes
seeing, the ears hearing, and the skin
feeling, one can become aware of the
mind sensing. Through practice of
this dance form one becomes able to
experience and observe the state of
one's nervous system particularly
when in an intimate physical relation-
ship with another. This spawns an
element of control over one's percep-
tual reality. This control and ability
to focus is training in developing pow-
er. Personal power and strength of
presence is essential in any performing
situation as well as in daily life.
Contact improvisation nurtures a
basic physical trust between two
people and among a group. The form
demands a care and consideration of
one's partner and towards this end
seeks to develop sensitivity and con-
fidence. This trust and the freedom
which ensues kindles a rich and fertile
environment for working creatively
with another person. Knowledge and
experience of this environment aids
in any situation where people are
working together, actors on stage
doing a scene, or dancers performing
a piece.

The working relationships which
develop in this form cross the bound-
aries created by sexual roles; men
dance with men, women with women,
and men with women alike. I do not
know of anv artistic discipline in
which non-~exual, deep, and honest
physical contact is explored with_ to-
tal equality relative to sex. In this
form women lift men as often as men
lift women. Women learn to exercise
a kind of strength which often has
never been encouraged, likewise men
learn to allow themselves a soft, re-
sponsive, and non-competitive posture.
It is a revelation to both partners that
a one hundred and eighty pound man
can be easily & completely supported
by a one hundred pound woman.
Again, the trust derived from freeing
the traditional sexual roles creates a
more comfortable and fluid atmos-
phere among any group of artists
seeking to work together.
Contact improvisation seems to be
of particular value for the college age
person. College students find them-
selves in an intense period of transi-
tion. They are coming to grips with
the image and reality of themselves
as adults. Thev are intently exploring
the psychological politics of sexual
relationships. This form offers them
a grounded, simple, and clear oppor-
tunity to interact deeply and honestly
with each other. It seems to serve as
a reference point or forum for expe-
riencing oneself in relationship with
others in an unthreatening environ-
ment and without the need to formu-
late consciouslv or to talk about what
is going on. The strongest evidence
for the emotional supportive value of
this work is the very real attraction
students have for this form. They
want to experiment and expand. This
form gives them the opportunity to
go ahead.
In and of itself contact improvisa-
tion has become a significant move-
ment within the dance world, recog-
nized bv audiences and critics as a
fascinating and evocative performance
experience. Many up and coming
dancers and actors are using the skills
they've acquired through practice of
this form to advance themselves in
their artistic work. Considering its
value as a supportive discipline for
the actor studying theater or the danc-
er studying traditional techniques, as
well as its presence as a new and viable
dance form, I feel no hesitation in
recommending to any college or uni-
versity that contact improvisation be
a permanent part of the curriculum of
any program in dance or theater.

Title: Editor Note
Text:
WHERE YOU GOIN' WITH THAT GUN I Setting Our Sights

"A writer is not someone who has something to say, he is someone who has found a process that will bring about new things
that he would not have thought of if he had started to say them."
William Stafford

The daily jogger, on the other hand, is focused more on internal movement sensations: the rhythm of
breath, the beat of heart, the sweep of momentum, the impact with the earth. Wheres/he is going is not on the map-
though s/he has to cover ground to get there. Though it is the movement and not the direction that is significant, a
direction must nevertheless be chosen in order to proceed.

For a long time it appeared that Contact Improvisation was more concerned with sensation than achievement and direction. There is the sense in practicing Contact that anything is 'right'. Anything goes. Yet there is a limit. How broad an activity can be before it has no parameters at all and we are left with what we call life, or in this case, human experience. When, in 1977, Steve Paxton observed, "Just the pleasure of using your body is, I think, maybe the main thing-in an unplanned and spontaneous way, where you're free to invent and they're free to invent and you're free to invent with each other-that's a very pleasant social form." However, it was by first establishing priorities that Contact was able to provide its particular kind of pleasure.

Contact can be seen as a means for communicating through physical contact. Dialogue proceeds, using the exchange of weight between partners to tune them to the physical forces that effect their motion and to tune them to each other. At the outset of Contact Improvisation, a choice was made to minimize the social content of the contact and to work, initially, with the physical elements involved in the exchange. Stated or by example implied, this choice along with others brought depth to the practice of Contact by limiting its scope. By narrowing the focus of the activity, subtle information was made visible: the experience of gravity; the "small dance" of the skeleton balancing erect; the flow of weight through the body as it rolls across the floor; the exchange of weight between partners during lifting, throwing and catching; the sensation of sharing a dynamic center of balance with another mover.

It has been 8 years since the decision to work with these specific physical elements. In this time, practice has revealed many principles that, serving as anchors, allowed the scope of partner exchange to widen. The practice of CI continues to suggest ways in which its principles and skills can be applied. Following these suggestions leads to fascinating work in dance, theatre, therapy and education. As the concern with physical contact and weight exchange becomes less of a focus in their work, many Contactors wonder whether they are still doing "Contact Improvisation". Others continue their studies regardless, not caring one way or the other what it is called.

Contact, as an evolving system, tends to attract the forces that work to open what is fixed, change what is static. Ever since its formation as the Contact Newsletter in 1975, Contact Quarterly has reflected this eagerness to find relevance in a broad range of sources. In considering the direction of our interests, as editors we ask ourselves, 'What does shooting guns have to do with Contact Improvisation?' In shooting, one tests the accuracy with which a message of energy (power) can be delivered to a distant point (moving or still). As a 'vehicle for moving ideas', Contact Quarterly shares that aim.

Title: The Politics of Contact
Text:
On Saturday afternoon August 20, 1977, some thirty participants and teachers of FOCUS 8/77 gathered
to talk about the Politics of Contact. The issue was as much one of defining the question or concern as it was coming
up with an answer. The discussion began with a minimal definition of politics: awareness of and concern for the
power relationships in a given interaction or situation, particularly those relationships which are unacknowledged.
or assumed and unquestioned. From this beginning the discussion was wide-ranging, spirited and largely unstructured.
Going back over a ta pc-recording of the seminar a month later, I have selected out and arranged (without
regard to original sequence) representative and provocative comments to share with the larger contact community.
To my knowledge this discussion was the first attempt to look at our work from this perspective and clearly it is only
one small step, but an important one. In retrospect, I saw our talk centering around two issues.· The first was seldom
defined as a focus but kept surfacing in people's comments: what kind of needs are filled by contact improvisation'?
Consuelo: I was interested in figuring out why it's come down that because of privilege like the $125
privilege and the class background privilege, why it is that this environment has developed around
contact; but I don't see that contact itself is this white cultural kind of ...
John: I'm not sure I agree with that, for one thing it's demonstrating the needs ... contact like anything
else is fulfilling certain needs.
Eleva: That's what I was going to say earlier, perhaps it's the white middle class that needs to get in touch
with their bodies.
Tom: What I see it gets down to is am I willing to go into the world receptively and attentively to what's
happening around me and to be in touch with my needs in a particular situation and other people's
needs. I really think it is something about the reason we're here is because we need to be here, else
we wouldn't be here, to learn whatever we're getting from this, and I see it very much in spiritual terms ...
this group of people is here to get what we're getting and I think a lot of people don't need it or are
doing it in another form.
Elizabeth: The same kinds of things that happen in contact are things that I think have happened to other
kinds of people in other situations, like in work situations where men do heavy physical work together
and might have to use their bodies in the same kind of cooperation and same kind of sensitivity to each
other ... but different than a dance situation ... which comes with a different kind of awareness.
Broni: Its purpose is different too.
Mark: This may relate to why this kind of event is strictly one ethnic group or one social class. I'm con-
cerned in society all over the country how it seems there's a great gap between this kind of situation
of workshops and focusing on a specific kind of dance and what I would call the masses ... their
desire to move and to socialize and be part of something which is being generally exploited. For
those people who are not coming to studio spaces and being part of something, the whole word dance
means to them Friday night and swallowing a six pack of beer and going to a bar or disco; I think
it's exploitative and I really feel there's a gap between that space and this space and it's really tough
to breach.
jerry: Contact has a lot in common with folk art and we are a folk ... we invent it as we go along, we
make it out of what we've got and the fact that what we've got is a college education, and money,
and attractive healthy bodies, and good teeth, you know, is different from having a bunch of ma-
hogany trees and a couple of rocks ... Contact improvisation has roots in dance, it was found by
dancers, and it has gone away from being a dance thing; it is a movement form. There are people
here who are not primarily dancers and the form is reaching out toward those people the way some
people seem to think we should be reaching out toward different classes of society or different
ethnic groups.
Mark: I feel that there are some aspects of this kind of dance that are slightly different than any kind of
particular outlet that supplies the needs for any particular ethnic group. I really feel that there are
some aspects of contact that are evolutionary .. I can't think, unless somebody can fill the space, of
other kinds of dance in the past which have been this free with sharing and this much touch and con-
nections .. I think this kind of dance is more significant in specific kinds of problems, like sexual
politics, for example, men dancing with men ... and even in the sense that it doesn't rely upon other
forms like music - goes right to an essence or centering ... This form of dance crosses a few more
bridges than others have.
Consuelo: You mean in the sense that it is kind of like a future vision of how people can relate to each
other in terms of sensitivity and activity?
Jon: In terms of sexual politics we're still dealing with one on one, two people getting together, and contact
gives you metaphors for expanding that to three or four or ten or twenty or whatever and that should
be explored too. ·
Keriac: Watching a ballet that gets into these boy.girl things, I don't get much metaphor for my life from
those; whereas I really find the material in contact, the interpersenal stuff that's happening in contact,
is a really useful sophisticated metaphor for what I'm experiencing. ·
Consuelo: Right now I feel really committed to art for change. It's really not enough to do a contact
performance for me, it really isn't. I feel like I want to know more what's going to come out and
deliver a message; and I don't mean just whatever message is there but I mean pretty specific messages.
Kris: There's something about pure energy that gets exchanged between people, we become something
of everything we are around, and when I see a performance I become those performers; and it means
a lot to me and it's the strongest and most pure learning experience I have and it's devoid of content.
It's not statements.
Consuelo: Well, that sounds like a pretty powerful statement.
I see that most of these needs in relation to contact have to do with the desire to break down the uneven
power of the various roles that people assume in relating to one another, be it male to male, dancer to nondancer,
or performer to audience. Contact improvisation as a political process can thus be seen as a means for bringing
people together in a way that prevents or at least discourages the assumption of roles and inequalities of power
which roles so often establish. There seemed to be agreement that, on an immediate personal level, contact achieved
this aim if the integrity of the physical form was respected.
The second issue of the discussion seemed to center around the kind of relationship the contact community
and the contact form is establishing with the larger society. Does and will this relationship maintain the same freedom
from inequalities in power and thus allow all people access to the vital (role-less?) movement relationships which are
contact improvisation?
Karen: The way to deal with it is to work on both levels - one is on the normal ground level of literally
dealing, believing that change takes place and revolution takes place within my own body first and
then at the same time being aware of where my body is: is it in the studio, in Cat's Paw, and that
door is closed unless I have $125, and then what do I do about that; and I think there are two dif-
ferent issues and both are necessary.
Brent: But we made this experience available for ourselves ... at least I did.
Karen: Because it is within your program in life to be able to do that. We're talking about a whole part
of the world where it isn't part of the program - it's not there ... so is art going to be something
we're talking about, an eclectic thing that stays where it is, or can this particular art form go out
because it doesn't have to have all that professional dilettantism that other forms have. Can it just
be a way of reaching people on another basis?
Laurie: Not right now.
john: This is a white middle class trip and other people out of that might not necessarily want to have it.
Laurie: And they might and they can't because they can't afford to.
John: That's not true.
Laurie: If one person wants to and can't ...
John: There have been set up free situations for people to study this and it is only taken by white upper
class people. '
Ernie: Sometimes it becomes a real trip that we are laying on them because we don't have the sensitivity
to know what they need.
Mark: What is the balance between being crusaders for contact and making it an available form for those
that are interested?
John: It is a manifestation I think in many ways of class differences and therefore class problems that we
should deal with; solutions are tough.
Evelyn: Most of the arts are a social ... I mean there's a certain class of people that do them. For a long
time they were a very elitest thing.
Ernie: But is it elitist? That word really blows my mind cause it's a power term. It assumes that if we
develop a dance form, it is automatically elitist. It's a dance form! ... something that came out of
our culture. Our culture may be elitist in a lot of ways - money and social structures generally, but
that doesn't mean the dance form is elitist.
Laurie: But it reflects the society.
Karen: I am forever grateful in one way, in an aesthetic sense, and in other ways, for things that have come
out of formalized, in a sense elitist, art forms and I value them. Then I hear what we're saying on the
other side. Now is there room for both ways to be?
Keriac: If you are thinking of contact as a folk art and experiencing it, it is quite a different setup than if
you are thinking of it as a performing art or a spectator thing. Like Karen was talking about, how can
we have both of these things, that they both enrich our lives? I think that it is facetious to say that
it is a folk art so that we can all rest our minds about that, you know, that we don't have to be con-
cerned about ... that we're clean; this is a folk art, it's ok. One can use contact lots of other ways -
the relative morality, the rightness or wrongness or whether it fits into your value system should be
examined.
Ernie: If you take something like contact ... and you can make it into where you're more sensitive to
life in general, the balances and flux of life in general, then it becomes evolutionary; but if you take
it and it becomes another package, then that's what it is, another package.
Some questions arc asked. concerns expressed and a dialogue begins. I hope the excerpts above may have
provoked thoughts in you and that you will share them with others. It is part of the dance. I hope that l have not
distorted too much the meaning of what people said by taking comments out of context or order. And in reading,
please realize the text above is in some sense my interpretation, my reflection, my recreation of what took place.
You had to be there. . . ·

Title: In the Course of Teaching
Text:
Accept your limits. I ask that students allow themselves the permission to realize their limitations.
I also encourage the sudden stretch beyond limitation. To see within this language the existence of
a subtle yet expansive definition of the word 'risk'. "Isn't that very risky?" asked a student looking
up at a friend pivoting in the valley between neck and shoulder of her partner. I believe this work
and other explorations compatible with Contact always involve the element of risk, whether we are
rolling along air-born arcs or standing still.
As flow does not mean slow, receptivity needn't be measured by passivity. 'Listening' is one of my
favorite words in describing the force behind transition.
Attention needs to wander to stay interested. In the teacher, your partner, yourself. Re-circulate.
Hearing Robert Creely opinionate that the full human attention is there for forty minutes.
The concern for rhythm and balance of class time. Developing trust in the quiet of before and after-
images. The forms of students moving, trucks on the freeway, the teacher's words measured and heard
by breath, inter-relate and create a whole entity.
The class assists a teacher in locating his or her placement between the skills of observance and verbal-
ization. Besides the basic sense of too much or not enough (alternately, I've been told by students
how there is excessive technical input or a frustration due to a casual and modest directive), we learn
to use the word if it fits. Of course there is still much more to say.
In one of his first introductory classes, asking: "ls the contact point the tension between trust and
responsibility?" In agreement - yes, Danny, there seems to be many levels of lifting experience.
Dancing well with new students is the most advanced part of my learning.

Title: The Small Dance
Text:
At the very beginning of a Contact Improvisation workshop,
teachers often talk about the 'small dance'. Why do _YOU start
with the 'small dance'?
STEVE: Well, first of all, it's a fairly easy perception: all you have to do
is stand up and then relax-you know-and at a certain point you real-
ize that you've relaxed everything that you can relax but you're still
standing and in that standing is quite a lot of minute movement: .. the
skeleton holding you upright even though you 're mentally relaxing.
Now in that very fact of you ordering yourself to relax and yet continuing
to stand-finding that limit to which you could no further relax without
falling down; you 're put in touch with a basic sustaining effort that goes
on constantly in the body, that you don't have to be aware of. It's
background movement static-you know-that you blot out with your
more interesting activities, yet it's always there sustaining you. We 're
trying to get in touch with these kinds of primal forces in the body and
make them readily apparent. Call it the 'small dance' ... It was a name
chosen largely because it's quite descriptive of the situation and because
while you 're doing the stand and feeling the 'small dance' you 're aware
that you 're not 'doing' it, so, in a way, you 're watching yourself perform;
watching your body perform its function. And your mind is not figuring
anything out and not searching for anv answers or being used as an
active instrument but is being used as a lens to focus on certain
perceptions. DC

Title: The Small Dance, Physiology and Improvisation
Text:
"Center of gravity" seems to have a lot of meanings for dancers. If you look the term up in a
physics book, you find about half a page; they seem to think that it's so simple as not to be worth discussing
a lot. But the concept is pretty deep when you think about it and use it to look at movement. Here I will
be talking about center of gravity in the same physical sense that a physicist would use the term. I will leave
aside meanings such as "center from which you move" or "spiritual center," and try to show the richness of
the simply physical interpretation. However, I am emphatically not saying that dance is "nothing but
physics" - more about that later. First I will explain and define the center of gravity for a rigid body, and
then talk about the more interesting cases when the body changes shape and the center of gravity changes.
C.Onsider the shapes in the first picture as made of flat cardboard, and imagine that you want to
balance each one on its edge on a pencil. Where would you put the pencil for each one so it would not
turn or fall?
Then suppose they were turned around, as below. Now where does the supporting point need to be for each?
OK, what does this balance stuff have to do with the center of gravity? I assert that there is a
unique point in or near each of these shapes, such that whenever this point is above the point of s11r--ort,
the shape wil I be balanced. This unique point is called the Center of Gravity. Another way to defin.
center of gravity is the point around which the body is perfectly balanced: if you stuck a support through
the center of gravity, you could turn the body any way, and it would still balance, not tending to tip in any
direction.
Now you really need to cut out a shape of cardboard and try it, to see if this concept works. Cut
out an odd shape like one above, but bigger. Put it flat up against a vertical surface like a wall so it can't
flop over, and balance the edge on a pencil. When you find one way it balances, hold it still and draw a line
straight up from the point of contact. Now balance it on a different edge,
and draw another line straight up from this other point of contact. The
two lines will meet, and this point of meeting should be the center of
gravity. Is it? Well, if it really is, then any time this point is above the
point of support, the shape should balance. TRY IT in other positions.
Does it balance? Try putting the center of gravity above the point of
contact but to the left of it. Now the shape falls to the left, doesn't it?
The diagram below shows the forces. The two forces (weight and support).
aiming past one another, create torque
that turns the body. Whenever the
center of gravity is not over the point
of contact, the body tends to turn and fall on the side where the center
of gravity is. It's as if all the mass were concentrated in the center of
gravity. We use this turning and falling a lot. When you are standing and
you allow your center of gravity to wander until it's not over your feet
any more, then you start to fall in that direction; you can allow the fall
to continue, or use the momentum to go into a walk.
To go back to the first shapes, here they are again with the centers
of gravity I found for each. Notice that in one case the center of gravity
is outside the figure! This is hard to conceive of, except if you try to balance the shape many ways and see
where the lines converge. Another way of getting an image of a center that is outside a body is to think of
a donut. For a donut, the center of gravity has to be inside the hole, no way around it.
The formal physical definition of center of gravity gives another perspective. Think of the body as
a set of segments, each of which has its own mass and position. The center of gravity is the point at which
the sum of all those masses times their (directional) distances is zero - the point at which all those masses
on all their lever arms cancel each other out. For a simple example, think of a seesaw. If one person on
the seesaw is a lot heavier, the lighter person can still make a balance by sitting way out on the end, to get
leverage. To be exact, each person on the seesaw has a turning force (torque) equal to her/his mass times
her/his distance from the balance point. So this combination in the picture would be balanced (assuming,
oh physics!, a weightless seesaw board).
Using the definition, it is possible to calculate the center of gravity for real people in different
positions. I analyzed these two pictures and marked each person's center of gravity with an X. The
tracing is my working drawing for the calculations of center of gravity.**
In the first photograph, notice how Nita's body balances around her left leg. Her right leg is
sticking out, balanced by her head and torso leaning the other way. The head and torso are not leaning
far, but they are much heavier than the leg. Her center of gravity is close to the "normal" position for a
standing person (inside the pelvis, a little below the belly button), and it is directly above her foot, so she's
stable. In that same picture, it's not immediately clear whether Steve is leaning on Nita or not. But see,
his center of gravity is not directly above his supporting foot, so he must be leaning on her, or be falling.
Comparing Steve's posture to normal standing, his left leg is tilted up and sideways relative to the straight
line of his torso, and his left arm is also up and to the side. Hence, his center of gravity is not so near his
belly button, but is displaced up and to the left. From the cases I've looked at, the center of gravity can
move around 6 or 8 inches from its standard position in the body - not a huge distance, but enough to
make a difference. Because the head and torso are so heavy (being about 55% of the total weight of most
people), the center of gravity tends to stay around the belly.
Llsa Nelson, Danny Lepkoff
The photo with Lisa Nelson nicely illustrates some points: her center of gravity is outside her body,
but it is still above the area of support, making a stable position. Note how her different body segments
extend to the left and right of the support, but they balance out. A lot of parts, particularly her legs, are
hanging off to the left of the center of gravity, but they are cancelled out by the weight of her torso and
thighs to the right.
We change center of gravity when we change shape, and often compensate so automatically that we
aren't even aware of it. For example, if I start out standing and bend forward, my center shifts forward and
I'd fall right over if I didn't make immediate subtle corrections. I allow my legs to tilt back, so my hips
are shifted back and my new center is above my feet. If you don't believe it, try this trick: stand with
your back against a wall, then try to lean forward without falling over. You can't because your automatic
corrections are prevented. However, sometimes our "instinctive" changes of center of gravity do not com-
pensate correctly. I used to do this one: when up in a "flying angel," and feeling insecure, I would try
to save myself by putting my arms up above my head and bending my knees. Then I'd fall on my head
fast, because both these moves shifted my center towards my head.
The height of the center of gravity affects stability. The further your center is above your base of
support, the less stable you are. Lying flat on the floor on your stomach, you are extremely stable, having
a low center and huge base of support. Now if you arch your arms and legs up off the floor, you are less
stable and find it easier to get mobilized. Why? Your base is smaller and your center of gravity further off
the floor, both factors making you less stable.
In Contact Improvisation, we purposely change center of gravity in order to move. When you are
rolling on another person, you change your body shape, the center of gravity and point of support change,
and you move - not because you have pushed or pulled yourself {and if you do it slowly, not by imparting
momentum to your body), but simply by shifting center of gravity and allowing gravity to do the rest.
When your center is no longer above the support, your whole body starts to move. This way of initiating
movement looks and feels very different from grabbing and pulling. I think a lot of the visual and tactile
thrill of Contact comes from support and movement that is non-grabby, non-invasive. Shifts in the center
of gravity of the person supported and shifts in support by the bearer lead naturally to mutual, shared motion.
In many situations, the idea of center of gravity alone is not enough for analyzing the mechanics.
When there is more than one point of contact, the center of gravity no longer has to be over a point of
contact. One easy example is a person standing on two feet equally; then the center is directly over a spot
between the two feet. Not bad. But if the person is leaning hard against something, the situation isn't
even symmetrical. You have to consider not only the two forces we've thought about so far (gravity and
the resistance of the floor), but all the other forces, acting at angles to one another, and how they tend to
push and pull and turn the body.
When a body is moving, the physics gets complicated fast. As long as a person is static or moving
so slowly that momentum is small, the center of gravity tells a lot. However, in analyzing real movement
physically, you have to consider momentum, acceleration, angular momentum from whole-body turning
and from turning at joints, and so on. For vivid examples of bodies in motion, look at pictures of Contact
Improvisation. Your eye immediately tells you whether a person was probably in motion, or whether
s/he could be stable in a particular pose. Your well-educated intuition fills in the blanks of where the
body must be moving to, what momentum it must have had to get to such a position.
One application of the center of gravity concept to a fast-moving body is quite useful, though -
that's when the body is in air. During a free jump, there are no outside forces on your body once you
leave the ground. As you go up, travel through space, and come down, your center of gravity describes
a parabola, no matter what your arms, legs and head are doing. At the top of that arc is where you have
minimum velocity (none up or down for an instant, but some in a forward direction maybe). Minimum
velocity means minimum momentum (momentum= mass x velocity), so that's the time it is easiest for
someone else to receive your body with least impact. If the other person then allows you to nearly follow
the curve you were on, the motions look smooth and little force is required, little impact is experienced.
This physics is all very interesting, but does it do anything for our dancing? Rarely, I'd say -
mostly in learning and practicing skills. For me, the physicist's view of center of gravity is quite intellectual;
I don't sense directly where my center of gravity is. I sense some results of where it is, as the pressures on
my feet as my weight shifts around, and other sensations. ---
What happens in dance does follow the laws of physics, but to view Contact Improvisation as
simply physics - or worse, to experience it as simply physics - is not my aim. Despite this long article,
I am wary of thinking and talking too reductionistically. I certainly don't want to contribute to making
Contact an abstract form that is only about physics and not about humans. Contact is about communication
and sharing, and one element we share is playing with the consequences of physical laws.
**FOOTNOTE
I used a standard but tedious way of finding the body's center of gravity from the maso; of each segment
and its location (see Wells and Luttgens, Kinesiology, 1976, pp 270-275).
1) I located the center for each joint (dots in my tracing).
2) I joined the dots and used "well-known proportions" (other people's data) to find the center of mass
of each segment; for example, the center of mass of the thigh is supposed to be 33% of the distance
from the hip to the knee. (X's in tracing.)
3) Taking an arbitrary point as reference, I found the distance of each segment's center of mass from that
point, measured as 'x' and 'y' coordinates.
4) Not having the actual masses of the body segments of each person involved, I assumed values from the
literature for the percent of body weight in each segment. Although total weight varies a lot, people
don't differ too much in how the weight is distributed, so this is reasonably OK.
5) I multiplied the mass of each segment by its 'x'-coordinate and added these products. Then I multiplied
each mass by its 'y'-coordinate and added these products. Thus I had the vector (directional} sum of all
the masses times their distances. Dividing each sum by the total mass, I got the 'x' and 'y' coordinates
of the center of gravity. C'3..

Title: Journal Stuff
Text:
Hooray, a few days ago I achieved a release from my bodily self-consciousness.
We were sitting in a circle watching duets. I had a typically uneasy feeling in the pit of my
gut. Should I go out and dance? Do I have to? I feared that moment when guilt outweighs
self-conscious embarrassment. What would my former lacrosse coach say, (a man I admire
and respect.) "Awww Agnew, you going in for that fruity stuff? What's wrong with you, boy."
Yikes .... I sat in the midst of a subtle form of panic waiting to dance.
A few feet away a woman got up. She was one of the better dancers and served in
some official capacity. God knew what. She started shuffling towards me. When she
reached me she turned and put her head heavily against mine. Oh shit. Who me? Putting
duty before my chicken heart I arose and we began to dance. Our movements were
synchronized. She felt vibrant, alive and at the same time soothing. I could feel tension
easing out of my back like water from a sponge as she rolled across me.
Delightful. I began to dance with a freedom and ease of movement I had never
before experienced. I felt her energy reaching into me. In sort of a psychic body massage it
began caressing my fears away. Even her most sudden movements were taken in stride,
sweet body of ours moving through gravity's pull like water through a sieve. We ended with
exuberance and a righteous finality. I rolled back to my place with a shining shit-eatin grin
spread clear across my face. Jesus, did I feel good. I felt great knowing the bars of my
bodily prison could melt and just dribble away in a few moments of dance. oO
