'plays'. CI has no point-system and
the maneuvers are relatively unpre-
dictable.
Dance has visual aesthetics, Cl has
accepted a much more 'general look'.
It just happens. Its subsurface currents
must be inferred.
I suppose we are asking audiences
to look in unusual ways, but what of
that? Every medium requires a shift
of focus, every culture. Even every
day. I would like an audience of
Sherlock Holmeses who would discern
the interpersonal currents, understand
the dialogue, and maintain a stance of
no blame, even in the face of the guilty
performer who could not fulfill his
own idea1s in performance.
I gather from what I have written
that I do not see the audience-perform-
er relationship as one where the per-
former has a duty to the audience. I
see it as a relationship where they have
a relationship with each other, and if
the audience may have expectations of
the performer, well, so may the per-
former have expectations of the audi-
ence. You no doubt get the drift. "It
matters what you give an audience to
do" (Christie Svane). "Art criticism is
for artists as ornithology is for the
birds" (Barnett Newman).

Title: Contact as Therapy
Text:
In July of 1980, Rita Ossi partici-
pated in a contact workshop with me
in Venice, Italy, for rehabilitation ther-
apists and others interested in Contact
as a therapeutic matrix, and thus began
a fruitful collaboration which contin-
ues to enrich our respective fields of
interest.
Rita was then doing psychotherapy
for a public health service, helping
long-term patients become autonomous
and reintegrated into the society. What
most preoccupied her about these pa-
tients was the sense of expropriation
that their bodies had suffered, the lack
of care for themselves physically, and
their fear or inability to adequately re-
late to others. She found that only by
direct means and experience-body
work-was it possible to improve their
self-concept.
As Rita continued to study Contact
with me in Rome, she found the con-
cepts of Contact Improvisation star-
tlingly powerful (even if some she had
previously encountered in Reich,
Lowen, Perls, and Feldenkrais): estab-
lish contact with yourself and others,
turn yourself upside down, feel weight
and energy, perceive and occupy space,
give and receive weight (physically and
psychologically!), understand where
the fears knot up inside. Each of us
from her own starting point was con-
vinced of the therapeutic value of
contact.
So last summer in Treviso, we held
a workshop together. Most partici-
pants said that their primary reason for
wanting to experiment with Contact
was to widen their movement experi-
ence. Little by little as we worked, we
noted that everyone found the work
psychically therapeutic also.
The workshop begins. After a brief
introduction, I start some Contact ex-
ercises: with the floor, with various
body parts, with space, weight, with
another's body (with and not against).
It is for them both an exploration and
a discovery, a putting into focus, a
union and a clash with their own sen-
sations and postural habits.
We go on to balances, somersaults
and other upside down movements,
feeling weight and energy, trying active
and passive roles. There are moments
when people seem confused because
they are feeling new sensations, coor-
dinations never before explored, rela-
tionships up to this point barely recog-
nized; and there are other magic mo-
ments in which the movement flows
as dance and everyone perceives the
fusion of mind and body.
When someone in the group encoun-
ters an apparently insurmountable dif-
ficulty, we stop. I try diversi:: physical
approaches. Rita mentions the sym-
bolic significance the movement might
express, the psychological valence of
that individual or group difficulty.
She tries not to be categorical but pro-
poses various hypotheses, interpreta-
tions which each can then investigate
for himself.
She gives some examples: not being
able to give one's own weight or take
another's may mean lack of confidence,
fearfulness, mistrustfulness of others,
rigidity in relationships; holding the
head and neck stiff perhaps means
wanting to control everything ration-
ally; holding the legs, especially in
couple work, could mean fear of sex-
ual invasion, etc ....
Memories of old traumas arise,
consciousness of habits (postural and
psychic) taken on at particular times
in one's life, fears that have never been
overcome.
When, on the last day, we put to-
gether sound and movement-roaring-
there is a moment of panic. Broken,
held sounds come out and they sudden-
ly realize that these sounds open a new
realm of the body. Eagerly and at
length they work on the impasse.
At the end of every day, Rita and I
discussed the work accomplished, in
what manner each participant had
shown us something of himself. We
examined our impressions of their per-
sonalities, their problems. The follow-
ing day I proposed exercises relating to
what had emerged, integrating this
work into the general development of
the workshop. And so the workshop
was guided by psychological as well as
physical considerations. The therapeu-
tic effect was confirmed by the parti-
cipants themselves in our final discus-
sion when they talked of their sense of
well being and physical pleasure, and
also of awareness, each at his own level,
of "dark areas", of the lack of accept-
ance of parts of their bodies, and of the
possibility of accepting those parts and
better integrating them.
Rita and I had decided not to com-
ment specifically but generally, to al-
low the experience itself to bring even-
tual insights.
Rita has been able to verify, even in
other situations, that the discovery of
certain personality disturbances, if it
happens in the body, with its own reac-
tions and sensations, is more quickly
recognized and can provoke more radi-
cal changes than an analytic psycho-
therapy based exclusively on words
which often mask, color, and dilute
significance and change.
Certainly Contact is a dance form,
full of life and expression, but we
maintain that it can be used also as an
efficient psychotherapy, or better, as
"body therapy". Both in Italy and
America where present physical fads
tend towards negation of the body
rather than self-discovery, we would
like to see Contact better known and
used. f!
I would be very interested to know
if and what anyone else is doing with
the therapeutic aspects of Contact
work. Irina Harris, 516 Nordhoff Dr.,
Leonia, NJ 07605.

Title: Random Notes from the Breitenbush Jam
Text:
Time's up. Now words must reach the paper. Highlights. It's history-no fancy
anybody's moving around like they owned the world. We owned the clock on the
wall; we owned the gold in our teeth. The sun in the morning, the hot steam in the
air, the hot sweat on our backs-we owned it. We owned the day before and the day
after. We owned the color green and the color orange and all the blues and the color
black. If my language offends you, forgive me. This is an ex-marxist speaking in
tongues. Anybody home?
It's good to get turned around, to get turned upside down because maybe for a little
while you don't remember where you are ie. disorientation.
I never counted who cares how many so many dances all different dances. I remem-
ber my black eye but not how I got it only that it felt (how should I say it)-earned.
Not a day went by that I didn't refer to a poem I'd been working on. No matter
how many times I tried to rewrite it, the beginning few lines always came up the
same: Dance/ a million laughs for El Salvador/ for god's sake/ Someone dance. I'd
started it many weeks before when someone I know was dying fast :ind was waiting
on what? I a miracle. And really I had never thought much about miracles since,
well, hebrew school in N.J. The light burning on Hannukkah was a miracle when
one day's worth of oil in a burning lamp lasted an entire 8 days because someone
with a fast horse and a few extra days to spare took a chance suspended his imagina-
tion and against all odds traveled to retrieve more oil.
Before the jam, the poem had seemed vague and simple and incomplete. Five days
later, without changing even one word it seemed to take root as a poem for the first
time. Before the jam, my words seemed to belittle the very serious political and
social aspects of the war in El Salvador but as I began to let go of the poem much in
the same way as I began to let go in my dancing the actual meaning of the poetry
became more clear.
Dance/ a million laughs for El Salvador/ for god's sake/ Someone dance
The current trend bespeaks the mood/ Bread and more bread/ and more bread
Noone is alarmed at nature/ Midwives slap each grave image
Sweat and muscle culminate beyond what waits
A broomhandle blooms/ and winks

Title: Editor Note: Still in the Middle
Text:
Last summer in Boulder, Larry
Fagin told me about an exer-
cise he gave his poetics students
as a lesson in improvisation: Go to a
movie in the middle. Sit down and
watch. As soon as you've figured out
what's going on, get up and leave.
For me too, improvisation is a prac-
tice in disorientation-training the
reflexes to read confusion as a challenge
not a threat; that a moment cut loose
from its moorings has the advantage of
being able to move in any direction,
and further, that a temporary absence
of reference points can clear the way
for impulses from unexpected quarters.
In the past few years, disorientation
has reemerged as a central theme for me
in teaching & practicing Contact Im-
provisation and in performing improvi-
sation. What began as a physical survi-
val skill for Contact, has become for
me a keystone-not only for the survi-
val of the bodies in contact, but for the
vitality & heart of the improvisation.
One of the earliest exercises in
physical disorientation for Contact
Improvisation, and still at the heart of
the work for me, is Steve Paxton's
'small dance of standing'. Relaxing
erect, the intelligence of the body is
revealed as it fires the appropriate
muscles just enough to keep the body
mass hovering within range of its verti-
cal supports. The micromovements
that occur to keep me balanced are so
tiny and yet so magnified, and arise
from such a deep feeling of stillness
and space, that I get giddy, tickled by
the impossible. magnitude of such subtle
sensations. The disorientation in the
stand comes from the feeling that in-
side the apparent solidity and stillness
of standing, there is nothing but move-
ment and space! Each time, I come to
feel as precarious standing on the floor
on two legs as I might on one leg on a
trampoline.
Without the willingness to risk one's
point of view, to be temporarily at a
loss, improvising can become a sleepy
exercise in restating what's already
perfectly clear. When nothing is really
at stake, one's survival is assured, but
some deeper satisfaction, both as a
watcher and as a performer, is lacking.
But it's tricky keeping the cutting
edge sharp-the body/mind adapts
incredibly fast to unfamiliar circum-
stances. What is attempted and survived
with hesitation the first time, is ap-
proached with more courage the next,
until soon it is done automatically.
After awhile the real challenge changes
from 'how can I survive this disorienta-
tion' to 'where do I find the next one?'.
It's easy to come into the middle of
a movie if you know when it's scheduled
to end. There's an added mystery to
the middle when the duration isn't
known. I love the performances of
improvisation that end themselves.
When a simple gesture, delivered with
every intention of being followed by
another, leaves you unexpectedly
finished. Realizing you're home, dizzy,
delighted, you say goodnight.
But most of the time it's the per-
formers that choose when to end. And
they have their preferences-sorne tend
to end on an upswing, others at a climax,
or just after, while some prefer to fade
away over the horizon of some long
plateau. I used to have a bad habit of
ending things too early-just when the
substance of the thing was about to
come through. Once a form was recog-
nized, I thought it was complete. In
my dances, I was constantly changing
the subject, interrupting with a new
thought, a new dynamic, a shift in
focus. From years of watching and
dancing with other improvisors, I slowly
learned how and why to stay with
things a little longer-that a form has
substance as well as shape, and to get
to the substance, you have to penetrate
the form. Recognizing the form gives
you somewhere to start, but it's the
substance that gives you depth.
I'm still learning that lesson. Both
Contact Improvisation and Contact
Quarterly have now passed their ten
year mark. Regularly, I sense the end
approaching, of my engagement and
curiosity with these forms. I feel too
well-oriented and begin to think I've
figured it our. But through the work
itself and my partners in it, I've learned
a little patience, at least enough to keep
finding out that what appears to be the
end, isn't. As it turns out, I'm still in
the middle.

Title: Editor Note: Now and Then
Text:
I've invested a lot in it, and I've gotten a lot in re-
turn. It is a generous form in that way. Smitten as I was
by the enlivened state it had the capacity to induce, for a
long time it seemed to me that the form existed totally in-
dependent of our insatiable pursuit of it. It gave but didn't
need.
I've since come to realize that the freedom improvisation
offers doesn't come without bidding. Its pleasure is a disci-
pline. In the practice of Contact Improvisation, one is con-
stantly faced with one's tendency to make the same choices
over and over again. Within the form, this tendency is
countered by working in close contact with a partner who
is in a position to remind you that there are options you
hadn't considered. Appreciating that invitation is one of
the basic challenges improvising offers.
I've also come to realize that it's possible to practice the
physical techniques of Contact Improvisation and never
make the choice to improvise. ls it because one hasn't been
shown the possibility, doesn't see it, or simply doesn't
choose it?
Though they greatly encouraged it, it was not only the
climate of the '70s, nor the improvisational forms it gave
rise to that enabled us to appreciate the value of staying
open to unexpected possibilities. The potential for open-
ness is human, and can be chosen and actively cultivated
any time, by any individual, through any form. It is the
desire for it that makes it possible. Like the fairy godmother
said to the destitute woman in a theatre improvisation I
once saw, "I can make your wish come true. But you have
to make the wish."

Title: Teacher's Notebook: Contact Improvisation Teacher's Conference
Text:
Accept your limits. I ask that students allow themselves the permission to realize their limitations.
I also encourage the sudden stretch beyond limitation. To see within this language the existence of
a subtle yet expansive definition of the word 'risk'. "Isn't that very risky?" asked a student looking
up at a friend pivoting in the valley between neck and shoulder of her partner. I believe this work
and other explorations compatible with Contact always involve the element of risk, whether we are
rolling along air-born arcs or standing still.
As flow does not mean slow, receptivity needn't be measured by passivity. 'Listening' is one of my
favorite words in describing the force behind transition.
Attention needs to wander to stay interested. In the teacher, your partner, yourself. Re-circulate.
Hearing Robert Creely opinionate that the full human attention is there for forty minutes.
The concern for rhythm and balance of class time. Developing trust in the quiet of before and after-
images. The forms of students moving, trucks on the freeway, the teacher's words measured and heard
by breath, inter-relate and create a whole entity.
The class assists a teacher in locating his or her placement between the skills of observance and verbal-
ization. Besides the basic sense of too much or not enough (alternately, I've been told by students
how there is excessive technical input or a frustration due to a casual and modest directive), we learn
to use the word if it fits. Of course there is still much more to say.
In one of his first introductory classes, asking: "ls the contact point the tension between trust and
responsibility?" In agreement - yes, Danny, there seems to be many levels of lifting experience.
Dancing well with new students is the most advanced part of my learning.

Title: Still Moving: Response to "Contact as Therapy"
Text:
In celebration of Contact Quarterly 's
10th Anniversary Year, we are reprint-
ing the 'still moving' writings on Con-
tact Improvisation that appeared in
issues of CQ now out of print. "Solo
Dancing," was written by Steve Paxton,
7 July 1973, Rome, Italy, following a
series of Contact performances at
L 'Attica Gallery in Rome in June '73,
one year after the first performances
of Contact at the Weber Gallery in
NYC. Both of these early Contact
events were videotaped and are avail-
able, in edited form, through Videoda
(see ad on opposite page). In addition
to reprinting older writings in Still
Moving, we look forward to printing
your current thoughts. This time no
material was sent in for the column.
Are you Still Moving? [Eds.]

Title: Response to "Dealing With the Heat"
Text:
Dear Nancy,
I appreciated your Editor Note last
issue, "Dealing with the Heat," {CQ
IX 3, Fall 1984], because I too, have
begun to see value in the friction of
opposition. I have felt my tendency to
harmonize conflict in so many aspects
of my life, from social interaction to
simply how I reside in my own tissue.
And lately, I have been exploring in
both my personal life and my dancing
the parts of myself that I had dismissed
by omitting 'no's, by resolving differ-
ences rather than feeling the heat of
the friction. I perceive that there is so
much ~o be gained in this exploration
and thmk that it applies to much of
what I have experienced with Contact
Improvisation.
To engage in conflict one must be
willing to draw upon the passionate
charge that emanates from one's
"guts'', tapping the heart of the mat-
ter. I am only beginning to appreciate
the value of this juice. I have avoided
it out of fear of sounding unreasonable
or being too ego bound. Now I see it
as a beautiful force that can orient me
toward knowing-viscerally-my sense
of purpose.
I see the basic aesthetic of Contact
as one of merging with natural forces,
going with the flow, and experiencing
union with both our partner and a
process of engaging the physical laws
of nature. Asserting control, saying
n_o to this_ union, or establishing a dis-
tinct self m the dance is generally not
done. As we continue to explore the
mysterious beauties of the original
aesthetic, I'm curious about how Con-
tact will change if we bring more of
ourselves to the dance, if our relation-
ships include difference and separation
as well as union, personal passion as
well as the impersonal play of weight
and balance.
I see the orientation in Contact Im-
provisation toward harmony and pro-
cess as an important voice on a leading
edge of our culture, evidence of some-
thing more spontaneous and essential
in dance and relationships than the
superficial and goal oriented nature of
much of our world. And I see the in-
corporation of conflict and passions
as an important passage if Contact is
going to continue to be a valuable so-
cial force.
In order to discuss this point and to
offer a perspective on Contact Improv-
isation in relation to our culture I'd
like to share some of the work o'f
Charley Johnston, M.D. He is a psychi-
atrist with a recently completed book,
The Creative Imperative, about a model
of all creative processes, from artistic
endeavors to the process of developing
a relationship, to developmental shifts
over a lifetime, to cultural change and
the creation of civilization . . . He sees
similar structural shifts through all of
~hes_e processes as they grow. Although
1t will be unfortunately oversimplified,
I'll describe the gist of this model in
order to offer a point of view on Con-
tact Improvisation's relationship to our
current culture and on Contact's own
development.
. The basic pattern Dr.Johnston ~es
m all creative process, all of life, is from
formlessness/essence/mystery into
form/manifestation/materialization and
then into an integration process that
eventually embraces both the struc-
ture and the essence. In other words,
~rom oneness into twoness, from unity
~nto separatwn, from what is archetyp-
ically fei:nale mto archetypically male,
from universal and spiritual into mater-
ial and intellectual; and then into inte-
gratwn. He _divides these three stages
mto five which I'll call: 1) Pre-stage,
2) Early Stage, 3) Middle Stage, 4) Late
Stage, 5) Integration.
I'll describe each stage with exam-
pl~s o~ developments in an art project,
a ltfenme, and culture. It is important
to note that each shift into the next
stage reflects a transformation into an
entirely different paradigm or system
of values. And each transformation is
a quantum leap into a larger capacity
for experiencing aliveness, for being
able to handle and even enjoy existing
amongst unknowns.
Pre-stage
This is a gestalting time, a time of
unity, before one is particularly aware
of a cr.eative direction beginning to dif-
feren t1ate from this womb of possibili-
ty. In a lifetime, it is prenatal experi-
ence and early infancy, when the child
bonds with parent. Culturally, it is the
time when life is ordered by connection
with nature-a powerful and mysteri-
ous ~orce. One lived within the unity
of tnbe which was inseparable from
nature and her cycles.
Early Stage .
The early stage is the time df inspir-
ation, the spontaneous possibility of
essence taking form, the first notion of
direction in creating a work of art. It
is childhood, a time of fantasy. It is
the time when cultures moved from
tribal nature to the sophistication we
associate with the early Greeks, the
Aztecs, and Ancient Zimbawe. Basi-
cally, life is still experienced as a mys-
terious force of which we are in awe
and by which we are totally influenced.
Many of the special beauties of Con-
tact Improvisation are reflections of
this stage. We dance with spontaneity
and participate in an often magical
process that is larger than ourselves
individually. Culturally, this is a spir-
itual time. Zen emerged from a culture
at this stage. Not until the next stage
do we become more personal, more
passionate.
Middle Stage
As the first shapings of inspiration
take enough form, they begin to chal-
lenge their source, their essence, for
attention and belief. Here, distinction
becomes very important. But not for
empirical insight-that comes in the
late stage. Instead, attention goes to
distinguishing right from wrong, good
from bad. As a work of art moves in-
to more formedness, the original
source acts as a sort of quality control
continually questioning the integrity
of the emerging form. At the same
time, the urge to form must continual-
ly forge ahead or it will be swallowed
by doubt. In a lifetime, it is the time
of adolescence. In the polarization of
forces arises a personal and even moral
charge, a strength to know your posi-
tion and stand up for it. (Sound famil-
iar?) In Western Culture, the middle
stage began at the birth of monotheism
and continued through the middle
ages. A result of that time was the cre-
ation of polarized social roles, e.g.:
aristocracy and peasantry, male and
female differentiation, and Christians
and heretics.
If we create a context in our Con-
tact Improvisation gatherings that en-
courages people to engage in polarized
relationships, then I'd say that the de-
velopment of Contact as a whole is
moving from the early stage into the
middle stage. In my recent past, I have
felt that emotional tension was a prob-
lem in a Contact class or Jam. It is
useful to me to see the value of this
stage rather than worry about conflicts
shattering the unified foundation we
have built. Actually, participation in
this realm can create a capacity to
meet one another in more ways.
Late Stage
In creating a work of art, the late
stage is the time when attention goes
to detailing the form and polishing the
surface, now that the original source
has taken satisfactory shape. In a life-
time, it is early adulthood when one is
more oriented toward establishing
oneself materialistically in culture.
With the age of reason and into the
industrial revolution, Western Culture
shifted into the late stage. The forces
of nature no longer appeared as a
threat as we separated ourselves and
focused on our capacity to control our
environment. We have developed elab-
orate structures both materially and
intellectually.
We live in a culture that is in the
midst of this stage. Aspects of Con·
tact certainly reflect it: we have a
highly articulate language for addres-
sing the skills of Contact-a surprising-
ly mechanical language of weights and
levers, when actually the essence of
Contact is union with natural forces
and diminishing our effort to control.
Integration
The next stage, integration, is re-
flected by the leading edge of our cul-
ture. The essence of this stage is most
apparent to me as I think of those peo-
ple who, as they age, become sagelike.
They come to gradually encompass all
of the stages-they appreciate the mys-
tery of life as well as the passions while
maintaining facility with the intellec-
tual and material aspects. With a work
of art, this is when the work is com-
plete and the artist becomes separate
from it. Even though you may have
created it, it will be quite a while be-
fore it is understood. Now it becomes
a distinct entity with the capacity to
teach even you who created it. I see
Contact Improvisation as an aspect of
Western Culture's movement into inte-
gration. I think it emerged as a coun-
terswing from the materialistic direc-
tion of our culture. It has served me
well in this regard. It has given me a
taste of community while all I had
known was transience. It has taught
me about shedding of ego to enjoy the
dance beyond my control; there truly
is something to be trusted as alive with-
out willful effort to make it happen.
These are rather foreign notions to the
goal oriented lifestyle of America in
the twentieth century. But what about
the twenty-first century?
Ultimately, integration is more than
a counterswing. Contact rather success-
fully synthesized the mysterious, the
more unformed and core aspects of the
early stage with the articulate, discern-
ing, and mechanical aspects of the late
stage. But in this time of overstated
glory for the intellect, I see much more
value in engaging the heat of difference
than for ideological articulation. In the
same way that revitalizing the teachings
of ancient prophets has been so mean-
ingful to expand our capacity for living
sanely in these seemingly insane times,
I think we have much to gain in re-
claiming the personal juice that is a
powerful part of the uniqueness of each
of us. I am excited to experience the
potential embodiment of the charge of
passions in myself and in connection
with Contact Improvisation as it grows
with me and with all of us. What will
these changes be?
Thanks Nancy, for all of your work
with the Quarterly and sharing your
growing edge.
Sincerely,
Kris Wheeler
Seattle, WA
Sept. 21, 1984

Title: Solo Dancing
Text:
Contact Improvisation is a duet art-sport currently receiving international attention by those insti-
tutions concerned with new departures in the forms of dance.

In the years since the inception of Contact Improvisation, in 1972, it has been adopted as perform-
ance mode by some 10 dance companies across the U.S., and used as a teaching technique by those
grass roots dance organizations, institutions and individuals concerned with investigation of d'ance
improvisation ephemera before the concerns of art aesthetics arise.
It is an activity related to familiar duet forms such as the embrace, wrestling, martial arts, and the
jitterbug, encompassing the range of movement from stillness to highly athletic. The exigencies of
the form dictate a mode of movement which is relaxed, constantly aware and prepared, and on-flow-
ing. As a basic focus, the dancers remain in physical touch, mutually supportive and innovative, me-
ditating upon the physical laws relating to their masses: gravity, momentum, inertia and friction.
They do not strive to achieve results but rather, to meet the constantly changing physical reality with
appropriate placement and energy.

Title: One Day We Were Exchanging Weight.
Text:
One day we were exchanging weight by standing shoulder to shoulder, hip to hip,
see-sawing back & forth. A practice in giving and taking weight using any &/or all
parts. I started with Diane (everyone paired up) and got involved in a familiar com-
fortable exchange. We switched partners & I started with Lori. We immediately got
into a gripping, grabbing, climbing exchange. We stopped & illustrated both partner-
ings to the others. I myself was very unwilling to dictate how the weight should be
exchanged, feeling that either method was valid and not wanting to assume or impose
a "contact" attitude. But what surfaced was fact. The duet with Lori was manipula-
tive (about power & control= outside forces trying to dictate or control action).
Hardly what could honestly be called an exchange. Safety was another major factor.
The forcing of actions & weight. The forcing of the situation undermined safety.
Injury not only seemed possible, but imminent.
I feel in the last few years I've rebelled against what I call a "contact" body atti-
tude. It seems that in the study of C. /mprov or in the development of the form
people have embraced a certain "body attitude" and approach every movement situa-
tion with it. I started yearning for scrappers. Rule-fess instincts governing a situation.
But in the actuality-in the exchange-if that's what it's to be-reasons for rules or
methods became very clear. I've always thought it a drawback to have to understand
& experience everything from zero, but questioning & testing sends you back to the
root, to the reason, and that's so valuable.

Title: Editor Note: Back in Time
Text:
Seven years ago, while doing a
Contact Improvisation duet, I was
stopped short by a movement I made
that wasn't mine. "Hey Lisa," I called
to her from across the studio, "I just
did your movement." "Let's see," she
said, as I rewound my sensations and ·
tried to do it again. Recognizing her
idiosyncratic timing, she laughed and
suggested I keep "doing her." My part-
ner was willing, so we continued as I
tried to put myself in Lisa's skin, in her
nervous system, and dance. Instead of
my usual moderated flow, I jerked and
flinched, turning abruptly, plummeting
halfway to the floor and stopping, pull-
ing my arms back like a chicken and
making tiny darting birdlike movements
at unexpected moments. "Whoa," I
said, wanting to stop, "this is too weird."
What made me stop was the eery sensa-
tion of being in someone else's body
and in their time. My choices, reac-
tions, directions and timings were total-
ly foreign to me, but at the same time
very familiar. I learned them from
dancing with Lisa.
There are many ways to learn some-
one's dance. In this case, I learned it
through the skin. Dancing in physical
contact with a partner is a lot like put-
ting your ear to a wall and having a
conversation with someone on the other
side of it. Like the sounds in the next
room, your movements and your part-
ner's are amplified by the contact, and
very little goes unregistered, even if
unconsciously. In Contact, skin to skin,
weight to weight, you're moved by your
partner's movements and in this way
able to feel their reflexes, the rush and
pause of their time, first hand. In Alex-
ander Neascu's article in this issue, he
talks of a new kind of time called 'in-
ternal time' recently identified by post-
modern physicists. I think it might be
this kind of time-one that moves ac-
cording to its own intrinsic logic and
phrasing, not according to the standard
clock-time divisions-that is communi-
cated during Contact Improvisation.
In "doing Lisa" I was further struck
by the fact that although these were all
movements I could physically do, they
were not ones I would ordinarily choose.
I had been under the assumption that
in improvising I was calling on any and
every movement I could possibly make,
but now I realized I was in fact doing a
very limited and consistent range of
movements, textures and timings. That
I was, in fact, always "doing myself."
I found this a rather humbling and re-
vealing discovery.
Looking back from here, the oddest
part to me is how disappointed I was
to realize I was only "doing myself"
when I danced-as if I should have been
able to do more.
What more was there to do, one
might ask. Well, Contact Improvisation
for one thing. Obviously one can only
do Contact, or anything else for that
matter, in one's own way, but I was so
busy looking at Contact Improvisation,
I didn't notice myself doing it. I was
too busy subjecting myself to "the
forces"-of gravity, momentum, iner-
tia, etc.-to notice what kind of subject
I was. And I was taken aback to even
consider it.
Within the study of Contact, the
experience of "flow" was soon recog-
nized and highlighted in our dancing.
It became one of my favorite practices
and I proceeded to "do flow" for many
years-challenging it, testing it: Could
we flow through this pass? Could we
squeak through that one, and keep
going?
I used to have a partner that I called
the Flow Machine. His considerable
mass streamed through the channels of
movement, sometimes like a rushing
brook, sometimes like molten lava, but
always ongoing. I would get euphoric
and giddy as the end of the phrase never
arrived-always there was a new curve,
and we'd bank off the edge of that one,
going on and on. There is great pleasure
in this. And it is in large measure
through establishing and maintaining

Title: Editor Note: All in Good Time
Text:
For the last month I've been going down to
Wesleyan University on Fridays to teach two l '12 hour
classes in Contact Improvisation. Though I've been liking
the students a great deal, I've been grumbling a lot during
the week about the classes being too short. But now the
grumbling is bothering me more than the shortness of the
classes, so it's time to look into the whole ordeal.
The whole ordeal is about time, not enough of it, or
more specifically, not enough of a certain kind of it.
When I teach beginning Contact Improvisation, there
are a few principles I come back to over and over-some
for safety reasons, others for flavor. Some have to do with
expanding one's orientation to space-experiencing space
as spherical, dealing with disorientation, being able to fall,
roll, and ride momentum, alone and in physical contact
with another mover. I suppose this could be called spatial
conditioning.
Then there's time conditioning, which I'm just beginning
to take particular notice of. A lot of the meditations on
physical sensation (e.g. Paxton's "small dance") that have
always been a part of Contact training are actually as much
about inducing an experience of expanded time as they are
about the physical sensations they point up.
This sense of expanded time is a subjective state, one
where time feels mutable and there are slippages-where a
45 minute dance can feel like 5 minutes, while a 2 second
fall can feel luxuriously long. It is a relaxed state, one
where time seems to have been released from its inexorable
unit-to-unit march and allowed to roam in an open field
with wide horizons and no fences, a time whose divisions
and textures vary according to the moods and perceptions
of the people moving through it.
As with spatial training, this new temporal experience
may be puzzling at first. All too often you lose your place
in the dancing, but you find out through experience that
if you just hang on a few seconds longer (those seconds feel
like hours!) your place will come floating up under you like
a pair of lost footprints. You come to trust and in fact look
forward to those gaps because in them you 're as vulnerable
and available as you can be, and from there come new per-
ceptions and some of the more surprising and refreshing
movement material.
But how do we get there from here? Especially when
we 're coming in to the studio from Chemistry or Shakes-
peare or Ballet or a 65 mile drive.
The transition from clock time to internal time can
begin during the personal warmup-a period of time often
given at the beginning of class to relax and "arrive," to get
ready physically and mentally to dance with others. It
deepens during the periods of extended duet improvising.
Absorption in the moment expands the feeling of time and
you come out of it enlivened no matter where you've been.
It's this state of absorption and enlivening that I aim for in
my own dancing and teaching.
I spent the first few weeks at Wesleyan searching in vain
for a quick passage, a trap door into this state. But how
could I hope to transmit the spaciousness, mutability, and
mystery of time when I myself was rushing to get in as much
dancing, skills, improvising, sensitizing, etc. as possible in
the 'short' time available?
Exhausted from my struggle with time, I gave up and
found that simply by relaxing I created more time. It felt
like practicing Aikido, where one redirects an opposing
force by first blending with it, not resisting it. Meanwhile,
of course, as I was internally wrestling with all this, the
students were rolling, giggling, getting dizzy, getting strong,
confused, inspired, thinking it was silly, feeling it was
profound and in general doing Contact Improvisation. As
has often been said, the dancing teaches itself, if the teacher
can only get out of the way long enough to let everyone
dance ....
P.S. After all this, I still think an hour and a half is too
short for a Contact class!

Title: Still Moving: Transcription: The Small Dance, The Stand
Text:
EUZABETI-1: At the very beginning of a Contact Improvisation workshop,
teachers often talk about the 'small dance'. Why do _YOU start
with the 'small dance'?
STEVE: Well, first of all, it's a fairly easy perception: all you have to do
is stand up and then relax-you know-and at a certain point you real-
ize that you've relaxed everything that you can relax but you're still
standing and in that standing is quite a lot of minute movement: .. the
skeleton holding you upright even though you 're mentally relaxing.
Now in that very fact of you ordering yourself to relax and yet continuing
to stand-finding that limit to which you could no further relax without
falling down; you 're put in touch with a basic sustaining effort that goes
on constantly in the body, that you don't have to be aware of. It's
background movement static-you know-that you blot out with your
more interesting activities, yet it's always there sustaining you. We 're
trying to get in touch with these kinds of primal forces in the body and
make them readily apparent. Call it the 'small dance' ... It was a name
chosen largely because it's quite descriptive of the situation and because
while you 're doing the stand and feeling the 'small dance' you 're aware
that you 're not 'doing' it, so, in a way, you 're watching yourself perform;
watching your body perform its function. And your mind is not figuring
anything out and not searching for anv answers or being used as an
active instrument but is being used as a lens to focus on certain
perceptions. DC

Title: Contact at Varick Street
Text:
Randy Warshaw joins her and soon
they seem comfortably connected,
rolling back and forth across the floor
at a pace that comes less from one
body on top or underneath pushing
another, than from the roving point
where the weight of the two bodies
meet. There is little eye contact, they
hardly even face each other. In this
dancing they don't need their eyes.
They're using another kind of sensing,
an awareness of pressure. The blending
of their weight gives them the cue. It's
not their faces, words or hands but
their backs, the nudge of a shoulder,
or a turn of a knee that whispers the
directions. Even when a spiraling mo-
mentum separates them, there is a
kinesthetic sympathy that co-ordinates
Randy's loop through space with
Nancy's spin and arched back suspen-
sion so that somehow he is underneath
to support her when she finally begins
to fall. This is the kind of crystalline
moment that Contact at its best is
known for. A physical communication
that is so immediate and clear, it
doesn't need added words or gestures.
Nina Martin and Danny Lepkoff
danced the next prolonged duet in a
style that markedly contrasted Nancy's
and Randy's. To begin with, they
faced each other a lot-they had to.
For without the eye contact and the
facial signals, their playful barrages
could have been seriously dangerous.
Hands that pulled the partner towards
themselves in an affectionate manner,
might switch tone and jerk the other
person away. The two bodies would
connect in a hip-check only to propel
off into separate directions. A lift
could lead to a sustained support, or
the lifter might just as easily drop his
burden and walk away.
These two dancers seemed to be
working from a set of character traits
that allowed them to spar lightly with
one another. Although moments and
movements suggested a certain aggres-
siveness, their flippant attitude and
laughter made it clear they were at
play. Their spirits were high and the
quick steps and fast, unexpected
changes of direction reminded me of
certain sports like basketball where
there is a constant shifting of direction
to outguess your partner-opponent.
Even though they rarely sustained
a physical connectedness, there was a
great deal of contact energy generated
between them. A line monitored the
space between them, a tension came
out of the constant questioning and
maneuvering in their steps. Finally
they did meet one time in a thrilling
lift that had so much momentum, that
it orbited Nina, who was spiraling on
top of Danny's shoulder, and Danny,
who was revolving around his own axis,
around and around the space. A burst
of cheer and claps greeted them as they
landed.
Good Contact Improvisation can
have both the exciting, funny, fierce,
mimicking, popping energy, as well as
the deep awareness of a physical com-
munication. The latter leads to the
former with skill and patience. But
what I see more and more frequently
is an immediate jump to the bouncy,
witty stuff of dancing. This is an easy
way to entertain ... for a while. It
tends, however, to run dry pretty
quick! y. I think this is because it is
not based on the deeper physical
source of the dancing, the real connec-
tion of bodily weight. Sure I like the
pizazz, but I also like the heightened
awareness that makes vision, words
and gesture less important than physical
sensitivity. u

Title: le European Contact Teachers' Conference
Text:
November 28 ·December 1, 1985
Theaterschool, Opleiding Moderne Dans
Amsterdam, Holland

PARTICIPANTS: Cathie Caraker, Walter Weiler, Celine
Theoret, Jaap Klevering, Jacqueline de Vries, Suzanne
Cotto, Jean Bloch-Laroque, Gonne Kooy, Moniek v.d. Laak,
Pauline de Groot, Elinor Ratleff, Wolfgang Graf, Bernd
Kammerer, Lulla Card, Didier Silhol, Regina Lamersdorf
(Nien Mari Chatz), Margot Rijven, Nancy Stark Smith,
Bruno Stefanoni, Keriac, Jozef Nadj, Mark Tompkins,
Joanna Bartholomew, Liz Irvine, Karen Nelson, Frank
Simmelink.

Meeting on THURSDAY, new faces, some familiar,
expectancy, excitement, why were we together? To meet
and dance, to exchange material, to discuss and share.
People from different countries-France, Holland, Britain,
Switzerland, Finland, Hungary, Germany, United States,
and Canada. English establishes itself as the first language
of the group with a continuing translation to French ...
already the spoken language suggests its power in group
interchange ... and as teachers, language as communicator
is a concern ... the word vocabulary translated from one
European language to another gives different meaning/
image/association ... and someone mentions the impor-
tance of non-verbal teaching/learning/communication. -+

Later, people offer their personal histories and some
insight into their ways of working and the situations in
their location. A recurring theme is personal explorations
in movement that give rise to the question, Is this still
Contact?, e.g., exploration of emotions in the dancing;
inter-connection with other disciplines such as yoga, tai
chi and Aikido. Recurring also a sense of isolation.

After words we jam. Non-verbal communication. The
energy is high. Much to explore. A common language
exists.

FRIDAY begins class with Nancy. Some late arrivals.
Guided partner dance warm up. Back to back. Each
ground. Connecting through point of contact. Movement
beginning in pelvis gradually including whole back surface,
legs ... gravity, momentum come into play, the whole
room is moving ....

Discussions around the most important aspects of
Contact and problem areas in teaching occurred in smaller
groups of 5 to 6 people. Later, reporting back to the
large group, some of the issues brought up:

Importance of observation for learner and for teacher;
the consideration that watching may be the beginning of
"listening. "

The usefulness of demonstration in situations where
people are unfamiliar with the work.

That teaching is a discovery; that people discover for
themselves; that change is constant.

To seek in teaching a process where the joy of move-
ment may be found.

Care to not manipulate whilst directing experiences.

Questioning how to teach in institutions where the
Contact class is compulsory for the student.

How to set goals in a given situation.

How to relate wi.th students' physical pain and injuries
and mental problems.

How to work with groups of differing abilities.

Talking about movement seems a more complicated way
of communication than demonstrating the problem.

How to be( come) ready in body and mind to lead a class.

Awareness about judging ''good-bad."

Knowledge and acceptance of limits and habits, and how
to work with them.

State of mind and how that changes.

Integration of solo experience into contact?

Working with imagery; shifting from inside-focussed
activity to outside-focussed activity. How to teach that?

Is there a way of experiencing weight (the first times) and
not get stuck in heaviness?

Is "weight" a state of mind?

How to create an atmosphere in a class.

Teacher is reminder for physical memory.

Can we be specific and still be improvising?

How can we share our "knowledge," experiences?

Am I still dancing while teaching?

Not necessarily emphasize difference between "begin-
ners" and "advanced, ".but creating structures that have
exchange happening.

At the beginning: important not to shock sensations of
body, but to build trust and confidence. Using awareness
of body-architecture.

How (when) to introduce subtle work like small-dance
or stillness-work?

Improvisation: the most obscure but most interesting
question in teaching.

Shifting activities while teaching: supervising, observing,
dancing, sensing, talking ... ·

Preparation: Nancy-"! make some notes,. makes me freer
to go in and to abandon whatever I planned. Can be a kind
of anchoring . .. Detours are often the most interesting . .. "

Teaching, what? Our personal concerns?

Moving with a partner: what's the range of communication?
(Contact and sexuality, Contact and emotions . .. )

Where is the heart of Con tact Improvisation? Where
are the borders from which it spreads and exchanges?

Stressing the exploration of the form in teaching.

Working in an isolated situation (or location) can
become a strength: challenging the development of
personal ways to dance/teach.

To give and take weight, fun, security, moving effortlessly,
confidence, unknown, open attitude, curiosity, the search,
extension, space (inner and outer), falling, relating with
ground, molecular dancing, elasticity of centre, transport,
travelling, inter-dependence, support, energy, rhythm,
balancing, momentum.

The afternoon is spent in trio feedback structure (2
dancers, 1 watcher, 20 minutes dancing/watching, 10
minutes giving and receiving feedback/discussion, then
switching roles, so all get to dance and to watch).

TEACHING EXCHANGE

SATURDAY begins with spontaneous warming up and
dancing.

The teaching exchange started with a discussion of
areas where people wanted to work-personal experiments,
ideas, difficulties, etc. We soon became involved in the
subject of being in the air. .

The initial question was how to use the force which
takes you away from center (centrifugal force) to meet
your partner again, and transfer that force into weight
exchange?

Here is an excerpt from the ensuing discussion:

Nancy: Maybe there's another way to approach from the
air that asks the other person to join your force-how do
you join it, how do you read it so that you can work with
it? To me it has to do with reading the movement before
it gets to you so you can join with it. So coming through
the air from different places, poses different problems to
solve in terms of forces, momentum.

Suzanne: How to stay flexible and open, to be able to
read that movement when it comes with so mu-ch forc;e?

Nancy: How to keep dancing in the air? People sometimes
throw themselves in the air, and then lose their sensitivity
while their partner just works with them. They are trying
to hold themselves together in the air and that makes it
heavy. They are not really there, they just want to get
down.

Karen: The place where you are being supported is a little
bit small, it's not like the floor ...

Mark: What about big men, I'm not used to relaxing in
that position.

Nancy: A lot of it has to do with if you're willing and
ready to fall frum any height, because if you 're completely
dependent on your partner or passive, you're in a funny
position anyway.

Karen: It takes time when you're up there to get used to
that, too, and to try to fall, in different directions.

Nancy: Also, when you're lifting someone who is big, to
feel that it's okay to let them go, that you can start and
follow through somehow without feeling that you have to
hold them up there-otherwise you don't even stlut, cause
you think it's too much.

Moniek: One step before this ... what kind of easy exer-
cises can stimulate this process-like rolling-for people
who don't have much experience?

Nancy: Falling is good, because falling is moving through
the air with gravity, and if people get comfortable with
falling, on the other side of the fall is something that comes
up. Falling gives you a force in an upward direction. It also
makes you unafraid to go down. The down goes up and the
up goes down, so if you can get the down part ...

Jaap: I'm interested in the problems of big men dancing
with small women. When I'm going up I often feel the
support collapses.

Elinor: It's usually the men that don't want to give their
weight to the women. They think they are too heavy.

Nancy: Sometimes I find with heavier people who are
afraid to give their weight, that they don't give their center.
The center is off to the side so I can't get under it to sup-
port it and then they think, "Yeah, see? Well they can't
support me" and so ... they just keep the problem going.
There are some men who are really quite large, and they
give their center and the weight stays alive and even if it's
a lot of weight you really can work with it a little bit. And
they feel secure and you feel secure, which leads to less
tension and thus more 'levity.' There's an exercise I
do sometimes, it's a climbing exercise and if it goes slow
enough you can feel and find your skeletal support.
There's no momentum involved and it's not particularly
light, it's quite heavy. But in the heaviness you find where
the weight can be supported and how it feels. Then later
when there's a little momentum it's lighter and you know
where the places are, where you can go to support the
weight (or be supported well).

Mark: Even if I go up, it's already become a habit that I
don't stay very long, so I never hang out there.

Jaap: I'm finding out that it's not the point to stay very
long, it's not the point that you're going up, the point is
that you're moving and you happen to be up.

Mark: But I'm talking about a technical level, as far as
knowing what that is, to be suspended in the air. I know
much less about it than you guys.

Nancy: Maybe something to do is just hang out up there
for one extra second. Again, it's like working with any --'*

limit-because it's a rhythm, up and down, up and down ..
so you're just stretching or,opening the limit a little bit
instead of 'how can I really stay so long' but just two
more seconds and see what happens.

Jaap: But there's one point-like when I'm dancing with
Jaana for example, she's small, and when she's on me I
have a lot of places for support, and when I'm on her she
is really so small!!

Nancy: People who are good supports really know how to
use the movement continually for support as well as
surfaces. There's really very little that the person up there
has to do because there's so much riding the movement
that's happening-with the little shifts to get around the
shoulders, etc. Sometimes I really feel juggled by people.
It's not 'cause they're strong but it's all the little stuff
that they're doing. I want to learn to do that more. (To
Karen) You work with a man about your size so you 're
quite equal in your weight support, which is a great oppor-
tunity, because sometimes women don't lift small women
either for very long, because they're not used to having
someone up there very long.

In the afternoon we had the actual teaching exchange.
The mats were out and first Karen had us practicing Aikido
breakfalls. Then Nancy led us in some light disorientation
practice and we went on to jumping on people who were
posts, approaching from the air and reaching your partner
while still in that light state.

During this session one question came up which seems
essential to Contact teaching: When working on skills, does
teaching specific movements or exercises have the same
result as teaching a principle and improvising within that
principle? How can you teach people to improvise if
not by letting them find their own forms and ways to do
things?

Later on, Mark led a class which encompassed focussed
duets as well as a dynamic group dance with brief and
changing encounters. Focus: dancing with different people
while still maintaining awareness of your original partner's
center, then coming back to dancing with the original part-
ner with an awareness of the group.

Suzanne led an experiment which was about accumulat-
ing energy and force during a common stillness in the
dance, while still in physical contact ... until the accumu-
lated force releases into movement through space.

Later, watching "Magnesium" and "Chute" videos
evokes a sense of history.

Post-dinner networking discussion brings us to the
publication of a European Newsletter and the setting up
of a European Jam.

DISCUSSION ABOUT NETWORKING

What is the reason for networking?

Needs, desires could be divided in:

• To keep informed about the places where Contact is
being developed: classes, workshops, performances,
addresses, dates.

• To know possibilities to meet and to dance with other
Contact dancers. Includes: knowing places and dates
where and when Contact is going on; organizing Jams
in Europe. Mark Tompkins reported about the experiences
with the first European Jam in summer 1982 in the country-
side of Southern France, organized by L'Atelier Contact.
Important points were the necessity of good space and
sleeping accomodations; costs (admission fee to cover space
and organization, then there's room and board, and travel
cost at the individual's expense!). Suzanne, Jean and
Joanna offered to set up a Jam near Paris around the 1st
of May.

• To exchange about teaching and research in Contact.
Possibilities: To invite another teacher to your studio.
To continue with this Conference once a year. Important
considerations: Who will organize the next one? The
necessity of good housing. Costs as mentioned above plus
possibly the fee for inviting a special teacher (the presence,
guidance and knowledge of Nancy was very inspiring and
supporting). The length of this conference was generally
considered too short.

To deal with these aspects brought up the idea of starting
a Newsletter. We should be clear about its aims: If it
should be to inform each other in a central way; or if it
should be a way of sharing experiences and exchanging
ways of working. We ~ecided to choose for the way to
inform each other, and to leave the sharing of the work
to the Contact Quarterly. Organizational agreements:

• Type your own letter (one page) with information
about your teaching and up-coming events in your area.

• Each time there should be a coordinator.

• Two issues a year to coordinate with CQ deadline so it
can be a part of the magazine.

• Send money to the next coordinator if you'd like to
receive a copy (or else it cannot be made and sent).

We finished the conference realizing the NETWORK
IS A FACT! -tt
[More news from this Newsletter and deadline information for the
next one can be found in the CQ Newsletter in this issue./

Title: Recognizing Dance
Text:
I am in a form. A form of discipline. Focused outwards and inwards. Making connections, which
make me to dance. I'm a mover alright. Eventually I'm moving the walls and the space between the walls.
Me, as a centering organ, as a source of strength. (One powerful enough command and I would fly up,
straight to the ceiling.)
What I really do is hard to explain. I'm the centre of the space around me alright, and also of everything
else, moving in that space. And it sometimes feels like it's me who makes it to move.
I know of course, it's me who's moving, but something inside my skull stays steady, in one place, never
shoving out of place ... however much I'm going upside down, through whatever angles. In fact, the more
angles I'm making, the more steady th is one part of me becomes. And the more steady this observing part
of me is, the better I can make the world around me move.
It's an interesting discovery. My body no longer distracted, because my organs no longer protest against
every leap I make. There is an adjustment which makes it possible for my mind to follow the body, and for
my body to follow the mind.
Moving around I'm getting closer. Moving around I'm opening up. Getting aware of other people in the
same space. Getting aware of other bodies (like mine, but different) moving around (but telling a different
tale). Getting aware I'm actually moving in space which is shared by all the other bodies in the very same
time. And by sharing this space, I'm sharing a conception. I'm sharing a movement, with every echo of it
rolling between the walls of the space, wherein my body is responding, like a boat on the water.
Effecting and being effected: my mind, with images. Mildly changing, disturbing changing, or however.
My body, in the space. And some of the bodies around me, dancing. With the same mild flow or strangeness
or confusion. However these waves in this stretch of time flow. And however much a mind is willing to
allow changes to happen.
My steady me is observing this. This part of me is the only part which doesn't let go. It's the part which
must lay hidden in layers there are in my brains. It's a part which comes out on those moments/in those
movements, when everything else is swimming in the stream. Comprehension. Understanding. Not the
detail. Not the current. Not the face that expresses and reveals, but a sort of silent memo. A sentence like:
"I was still, no movement at all." Which is nothing more than recognizing a situation and accepting the
absolute truth of it. Which means that on that moment, there is a balance of forces, focused on the moving
body. And the observation of such is the key of control.
Then my steady part falls back inside its hidingplace and there are only all of my senses left, sprawling in
the dance. Dancing with other bodies, all in the same room. Space, time separating. An improvisation
about survival.
Going around somebody's back, falling down, head first towards the floor, rolling, jumping up. Waiting,
out of balance. Being out of balance all the time. That's the essence of this dance form.
Trying to cope with that which moves around you. Trying to grasp a shift of weight. Feeling the floor
move away and around. Focusing eyes, sensing ears, balancing feet, flexing spine.
Finding a way to the end of that rope. Landing on hands and feet. Feeling the ground getting to rest,
while sitting. Waiting for echos to finally fade. Walls becoming walls and bodies becoming personal objects.
A sense of distance restored once more ...

Title: Editor Note: Taking No For an Answer
Text:
At some point in the growth of Contact Improvisation
there was a call for definition, rules, a clear way to identify what
was (or wasn't) Contact Improvisation. ("There are no lines,
only edges." Ansel Adams) Only a few years after its inception,
Contact seemed to be spawning generations of contacters so
quickly as to be involved in some kind of 'telephone game'.
John tells Sally who shows Sue who passes it on to her brother
who tells his wife who shows their kids who bring it to school
the next day for recess. If John were walking by the schoolyard
at noon, would he recognize anything familiar going on in the
playground? For all the interest in defining Contact Improv-
isation, the answer to that quandary is in watching a contact duet
between two dancers who have just met. The definition is in
the doing.
Contact bases its language on the natural laws that govern
motion (gravity, momentum, inertia, etc.). With these laws as
our constitution, we have no need for legislation. The natural
world enforces its own laws - drop a book, consciously or not,
and it wil I fall. Clearly, Contact Improvisation is not the begin-
ning or the final stage in the opus that relates the body and its
movements to the earth and the other movers on it. The truths
we find in Contact, whether basic or elevated, are truths that
exist with or without Contact Improvisation as a means for re-
vealing them to us. Often in the enthusiasm of the work it is
possible to forget that bodies moving in contact are not new.
It is, however, the continued focus on the elements involved in
that contact, techniques for it, applications of it, that is specific
to Contact Improvisation.
Making a magazine (CQ) for the exchange of information
and viewpoint instead of making a congress, allowed the various
subtexts that existed to emerge and be shared. As a technique
for moving together, Contact resonates in the lives of the prac-
titioners. Those resonances are personal and varied, and though
they enrich the work, the basic practice seems unchanged.
After 6 years, Contact Improvisation continues, with
or without music, in twos, threes, in groups with a name or with-
out. Contacters have gathered in bodies, regional families, to
corroborate and continue. A context has developed similar to
social dancing wherein people can come together and 'jam'.
Tiirnugh Contact Quarterly a network exists, making known
places where Contact can be found. When a poker player comes
into a new town, he looks for the game.

Title: Still Moving: The Awareness of Change
Text:
The state or space created in
the workshop setting decreases
the stimuli of the outside world
so that the internal impulses of
our dancing can be felt, seen and
acted upon. Once the outer
arrangement has less of an influ-
ence, then the inner space be-
comes fuller, more alive and its
range of possibilities become
wider. The awareness of change
in the inner space becomes vivid
so that when the outer space of
our world increases its influence,
we do not lose the ground we
have gained from the inner world.
These statements were gleaned
from a month's worth of writings,
thoughts and discussions I participated
in at Naropa Institute Summer 1986.
However vague and general, they seem
to apply to the state of mind we reach
when awareness is brought to our
dancing. During the course of the four
weeks of Contact Improvisation classes
taught by Nancy Stark Smith, we talk-
ed a lot about the "Ready State,"
never actually defining it, but neverthe-
less knowing when it had occurred.
There never seemed to be a standard
way of preparing the body to dance,
but one ingredient was always required.
Awareness of body sensation, move-
ment and body/mind states. Once in
the "Ready State," every part of our
being participates actively. When not
ready, some part of us hangs back,
watches, refusing to participate, creat-
ing a rift within our own dancing and
between us and our partner.
It seems that awareness implies
action, and if this is true, then in the
"Ready State" of Contact Improvisa-
tion we must actively know our sensa-
tions, movement and mind states. To
know actively, or to bring awareness to
dancing allows expression; the exchange
of one body of knowledge with anoth·
er. In my ignorance, I seemed to think
that the "Ready State" was something
to be achieved. A way of doing this
was to identify the stages one might go
through to reach the "Ready Stire."
They came as follows:
1. Getting into the body-requires
a shifting of mind into bodily terms,
i.e., sensation, imagery and movement
quality.
2. Body time-now in the body,
the action is of deepening quality.
3. Body Sensitivity---,body sensation
and states of mind become finely
tuned. The sensitivity to and aware-
ness of body sensation and body minds
is increased.
4. Body Expression and Exchange-
moving out of inner sensation and into
exchange with a partner. The body be-
comes the mode from which I relate.
Although these stages offered some
insight into the process, they also told
me something about my ambition to
achieve something that I thought was
necessary. The "Ready State" requires
only to be where you are, not where
you think you should be. This slight
shift means bringing an awareness to
the changes happening in our dancing;
changing and guiding the changes as
well, so that the dancing becomes an
exchange between the inner and outer
impulses. This awareness is full bod-
ied, the mind responds to the body
and the body responds to the mind. It
is a way of being with change. Being
comfortable with frustration, ambigu-
ity and basically not knowing what
comes next. A way of being which
begins without expectations of what
will come, freeing you to be with
whatever is occurring.
In looking back at the time spent
at Naropa, I see that we seemed to
create a space for ourselves that aimed
for freedom from distraction. We
cleared and prepared ourselves to
dance in the most honest way we knew
how. The discipline of Contact Im-
provisation requires this clarity of
body, mind and spirit, so that the
person can deepen within the form
and of equal importance, enjoy their
dancing.{::{

Title: Teaching Score 1: "Puppet-Puppeteer"
Text:
I started the class off with unstructured solo warm up, asking for people
to soften, and to move without working at it, and then continue in this mode
into a slow duet warm up dance with the same qualities. The material that I
presented was what I call the puppet-puppeteer motif. I developed this style
of movement out of an image from a Robin Feld class working with manipu-
lations. She was dressed in black and was moving a colorfully dressed person.
I asked people to start off with a light touch, suggesting working the pup-
pet by the upper body from behind, using the puppet's upper arms, or by
pulling and leading from in front. The puppeteer does all the initiation; the
puppet can follow through but not initiate. For example, the puppeteer can
move the puppet's arm up and the puppet's arm can then slowly float down
like a feather. Then the quality can get heavier, the puppeteer can bring the
puppet into his or her center, taking more weight, nurturing and caring for
the puppet; finally bringing the puppet to the floor, rocking it and putting it
to sleep. I used this motif in a section of a dance that I created and performed
in New York, June 1985, called "The River of Cause (because because because
because because)."

Title: Notes on the
Text:
The jam/conference was a dialogue
between doing and contemplation,
playing freely and then defining what
seemed to be happening. It was a spa-
cious time where together we sculpted
our shifting understandings of the
work.
One of the joys of this process of in-
quiry was its immediacy-the being
able to move from a stimulating discus-
sion straight into dancing-or coming
upon a discovery dancing ... and
having the context, right there, to im-
mediately share it with someone, or
the group ... so to articulate the
elusive find .. .
In this setting the work was given
range, depth, and focus-we experi-
enced it as a vehicle of personal expres-
sion and development and as an influ-
ence in the structure of today's society.
And the conference was about
COMMUNITY.
Other than finding out about the broad
and concentrated research that is hap-
pening, I recall the connectedness and
power I experienced'there. I've been
in many group situations and worked
on many projects, but I've never felt
such a strong, nurturing, and inspiring
sense of community.
There were no leaders or followers-
rather we were all leaders and follow-
ers, speakers and listeners, guides 'and
journeyers. There were plenty of op-
portunities for both taking in new in-
formation, ideas and processes-and
presenting ideas or formats or situa-
tions. It happened in structured ways-
such as the classes where four different
people would take a segment and pre-
sent an approach to teaching-and it
happened in informal meetings, dia-
logues, and dances.
This in itself was a melding of idea and
practice. One evening Steve Paxton got
into a 'where-does-contact-improvisa-
tion-fit-in to-the-history-of-dance' talk,
and described that one of the roots of
contact was its aim to break with the
conventional representations of social
structure; to deal with relationships
between people on a more anarchistic/
democratic level.
And true to its form, this open struc-
ture allowed a lot of energy to be ex-
changed. Not only did we discover our
similarities, but also our differences.
There were questions of style & process
& orientation that were not always
easy for people to negotiate-yet a will-
ingness to encompass it all and work it
through pervaded. And again, the flu-
ency .between these states was really
excmng, and I find, now gives me a
new perspective when working with
peers. Something about keeping the
space open enough to allow for the
free flow of input from all.
And we looked at the question of
PERFORMANCE ... is performance a
relevant part of contact improvisation?
. .. is it appropriate to put the work
out for audiences to see? One answer
was Steve Paxton's comment, "Yes.
For me, performing is the reward you
get for being allowed to handle the
idea."
Performance is putting the work into a
domain where other people can respond
to it, where the ideas & forms will be
examined and thereby shaped.
In the performance setting, the audi-
ence is bringing a mindset-this helps
bring the evocative power of allegory
and metaphor to the activity of the
dance.
And one of the values of performance
in improvisation to me is simply the
looking for ways to shape the work-
( or have the Work shape itself) into a
self-complete form, being able to tran-
scend the realm of research and move
into the realm of .... at least some-
thing which is enjoyable for people to
watch, participate in through watching
and reacting, through the natural use
of metaphor-putting their life into
action-out there, and providing for
the audience, just through the sheer
pleasure of the movement, the oppor-
tunity for them to relate to ....
WEIGHT
rising and falling
floating
diving
up
rushing
bouncing
hang-gliding
jagged free jazzing
So in the dancing (as well as in consid-
ering the direction the work as a whole
is t~king) it's all about "being able to
be m the spaces of uncertainty & am-
biguity with confidence ... "
We were considering the question,
"What is contact improvisation?," and
Nancy's comment was, "a group like
this preserves the recipe."
The work is, and will become, what
we bring to it.
THIS COMMUNITY IS EXPLORING
ITSELF. i:

Title: Teaching Score 2: "Trio Contact Point"
Text:
Accept your limits. I ask that students allow themselves the permission to realize their limitations.
I also encourage the sudden stretch beyond limitation. To see within this language the existence of
a subtle yet expansive definition of the word 'risk'. "Isn't that very risky?" asked a student looking
up at a friend pivoting in the valley between neck and shoulder of her partner. I believe this work
and other explorations compatible with Contact always involve the element of risk, whether we are
rolling along air-born arcs or standing still.
As flow does not mean slow, receptivity needn't be measured by passivity. 'Listening' is one of my
favorite words in describing the force behind transition.
Attention needs to wander to stay interested. In the teacher, your partner, yourself. Re-circulate.
Hearing Robert Creely opinionate that the full human attention is there for forty minutes.
The concern for rhythm and balance of class time. Developing trust in the quiet of before and after-
images. The forms of students moving, trucks on the freeway, the teacher's words measured and heard
by breath, inter-relate and create a whole entity.
The class assists a teacher in locating his or her placement between the skills of observance and verbal-
ization. Besides the basic sense of too much or not enough (alternately, I've been told by students
how there is excessive technical input or a frustration due to a casual and modest directive), we learn
to use the word if it fits. Of course there is still much more to say.
In one of his first introductory classes, asking: "ls the contact point the tension between trust and
responsibility?" In agreement - yes, Danny, there seems to be many levels of lifting experience.
Dancing well with new students is the most advanced part of my learning.

Title: Freelancing With Contact
Text:
This piece was written in 1979. We
discovered it in our files and found the
issues in it still very much alive. We
talked with Paul about it and be agreed.
He also noted that shortly after this
period, performances of improvisation
in New York City seemed to disappear
for several years. [Eds.]

I suspect there are many
people presently involved in moving
art forms who, except for exposure to
contact improvisation, would not have
entered the field. My experience is a
case in point. As an art major in col-
lege, I enjoyed creating large sculptural
environments for the body. The
weight and awkwardness of the mater-
ials, plywood, two-by-fours, and other
construction hardware, turned building
a piece into a physical work-out.
Sculpting was an arranging dance,
using the whole body.

During this time (1973), Curt Sid-
dall, Nita Little, Steve Paxton, Nancy
Stark Smith, and someone whom I re-
member well except for her name
[Karen Radler] came to perform and
teach contact on the west coast for
the first time. I danced some and
watched a lot. The idea of people
presenting natural movement as a
performance was a pleasant jolt to me.
The democratic give and take between
partners was appealing. Improvising
dance, creating while performing was,
for me, a revelation. And my person-
ality was more comfortable with the
social circumstances of dancing than
the solitude of sculpture.

My first dancing was suffused with
comparisons between sculpture and
contact. It was as if the four-by-eight
plywood sheets I had been building
with developed power steering, and
could even lift me off the ground.

The three-dimensional experience of
sculpture became four-dimensional,
the fourth dimension being the time
of the dance. I was no longer the
manipulator. For every impulse of
mine, there was another independent

nervous system deciding what was hap-
pening as well. I saw that contact is
very purely about process. In terms
of sculpture, that meant showing how
fascinating it is to make a piece, rather
than showing a finished piece.

Through performing, I like letting
others in on the creating side of the
work, the side most interesting to me.
Since that time, I've performed in
many different situations; contact,
other improvised structures, and set
pieces. In watching dance or perform-
ing it, I'm drawn to dancing which
doesn't impose a style on the people
who dance. This may partly be a
hangover from art training which en-
courages students to find an individual
vision from the start of training. I'm
glad this idea has a lot of credence in
the dance world now.

Improvisation is one way of work-
ing individualistically either in a group
or solo. A problem is that improvisa-
tion and performance are sometimes
friends. We all know of our on nights
and our off nights. Those who perform
improvisation have decided that the
pluses outweigh the minuses. The
pluses are that the dancers are present-
ing a raw slice of life, uncut, uncooked.
The audience's position is elevated be-
cause they are allowed to get in on the
whole story as it happens for the first
time. They aren't watching something
which has been edited in rehearsal.

Improvisation is risky and often re-
warding for the performers. It is a way
for performers to move on with work,
not to stick with an image or sequence
which must be repeated several times.
The formal qualities of contact make
it a focused and grounded improvisa-
tional technique. There is a basic
agreement between performers which
provides a continual springboard into
the dance. A performer of contact has
a lot of freedom.

I'm sitting here writing about how
good a performance improvisation
makes, and resisting tooth and nail the
detractions. However, there are some.
There is no overall structure to control
the impact of the performance. It's
like having several small dances linked
together. Dull repetition can be a
problem. When this happens, it's like
watching the same rehearsed dance
several times in one piece. This is one
of the main limitations in previous
dance work which many of us are try-
ing to avoid by investigating improvi-
sation. An ideal piece has few seams
showing. There are a lot of ways to
approach this, but they mostly have to
do with pre-planning. It's difficult to
achieve in an improvised performance.
There also are some beautiful possibili-
ties in pre-setting a piece; it can have
long sections of synchronized move-
ment, it can be a story, it can have
special timing, or it can deal with the
personae and not the personality of
the performer. The search for these
qualities is improvised but their presen-
tation is, for the most part, set.

Safety is important in contact.
This results in contact being playful,
game-like, and positive. There is a
utopian communal quality to contact-
a great experience but not the whole
picture. This one-keyed quality can be
limiting for an audience, and make
performing frustrating. There is little
room to explore subjects like discord,
tragedy, or events which are fantastic
or grotesque. Sometimes I want to
entertain/be entertained with these
rich images. Sometimes I want the
purity and abstraction of contact.

When I perform contact, I like to
feel that we, the performers, are shar-
ing the performance with the audience.
Among the most satisfying perform-
ances in this respect was a series done
at the Paula Cooper Gallery in New
York City [1978). We performed in
