was the only way to fill the class.
Nevertheless, the first class went
well. People candidly verbalized their
excitement as well as their discom-
fort. We worked deeply and gently
on cellular awareness, yielding into
the floor and through a partner to
the floor. We practiced thrusting in-
to the resistance provided by a part-
ner's body. By the end of the class,
people seemed satisfied and expand-
ed, more confident about their abili-
ty to take care of themselves and to
learn in this environment. I relaxed
about the class, feeling that the
group's energies would mix well and
that the more experienced would
both encourage and learn from the
beginners.
One woman never came back. On
the phone she told me that the class
was too scary for her. Over the
weeks more people came and went.
Never knowing exactly who or how
many would show up, I felt bullied
by the inconsistency. I wanted to be
open to the energy at hand, but was
subtly angry that I couldn't count on
people at the very least to be there. I
felt unmet, frustrated that I couldn't
generate momentum by building on
previously taught skills. It was like
teaching a perpetual first class.
By the last class of the series only
six people remained. And during that
class, even the few remaining people,
one by one, began to leave. Someone
slipped out of a group improv in
which people had the options to
move, watch or draw. When I went
to tell her good-by, she "playfully"
punched me in the stomach, saying
she had left a drawing for me. I
looked at the drawing and found it
full of anger about how I had led
that day's class.
I could hardly focus on the three
remaining women, still entwined in a
tender, playful dance. When we
finally- gathered in a circle, I shared
how difficult it had been for me to
remain present with the dancing
while others left the class. They said
they had been so engrossed in what
they were doing, that they had not
noticed the others leave. They
assured me that they had had a
wonderful time, told me how much
they had learned through the whole
series, and encouraged me to keep
developing the work. As they spoke,
my little-girl feelings of shame and
abandonment drained away. I realiz-
ed that I had been paralyzed by
"shoulds," voices in my head like
the voices of my former mentors in
the dream, criticizing my choices as a
teacher, telling me how I had failed
to deliver.
In the weeks that followed, people
who had disappeared from class and
some who had seemed ambivalent
called to tell me how important the
work had been to them and were
eager to sign up for the next series. I
could see that in allowing more parts
of myself to be present in class, I
had opened the door for more parts
of everybody to be there. However, I
didn't know how to fully support
this process which, while sometimes
allowing people to tap into nurturing
and delightful movement, at other
times brought them up against their
deepest patterns of discomfort.
I have always understood Contact
Improvisation as a healing activity.
Through my study of developmental
patterning, I now understand more
specifically that I was drawn to Con-
tact not only by love of movement,
but also by my vast unsatisfied need
for nurturing, non-sexual touch,
especially for compression, the kind
of pushing into the body that, as in-
fants, tells us where we are, gives us
our sense of self. Pushing against
resistance allows us to develop the
strength to reach beyond ourselves
into our environment. While modern
dance training helped me reclaim my
body as a source of learning and ex-
pression, Contact Improv satisfied
my need to connect with others
directly, through bodily sensation
and the physical laws of motion that
affect us all. Having the weight of
my adult body met, I rediscover
baby joy, trust and expansiveness.
Yet, offering ourselves these
pleasures may restimulate old hurts,
fears and unresolved conflicts that
live in our tissues, in the very pat-
terns of our movements. The people
coming to my classes these days are
not necessarily dancers or even
"movers." They are people on a
pathway of personal growth, in-
terested in expanding the range of
choices in their lives. Many have
mapped their emotional, spiritual or
energetic terrain, but still experience
their bodies as largely unexplored
territory. They want to understand
how inner movement translates into
movement in the world of form,
space, objects and relationships.
They may appreciate the importance
of hanging out with emotional or
spiritual discomfort in order to free
up old patterns, but may never have
experienced this process in their
bodies, challenged by gravity,
momentum, and other people's
physical presence.
In my classes I had created permis-
sion for people to move with their
bodies' desires. But at some deeper
level in myself, I was still taking
responsibility for the "success" or
"failure" of the class. Judging that
success (and myself) by how unified
the energy of the room felt, how ful-
lly people disclosed their experience,
how much they said they had learn-
ed, what the dancing looked like, I
was still not comfortable with each
person having their own experience
of the class. Because my sense of
self-worth depended on my judgment
of the feeling in the room, none of
us were completely free to enjoy the
sense of individuality which would
support our interconnectedness.
Gradually, I have come to ap-
preciate in my teaching what I ex-
perience in my dancing: meeting
resistance, physically and emotional-
lly, creates support. Defining a
boundary-where you end and
something or someone else begins-
empowers you to reach beyond your
own kinesphere, past the edge of
your known experience. Yet, at
another level of perception, what ap-
pears solid and static can be perceiv-
ed as spacious and moving: a wall or
a person that seems an impermeable
barrier may be viewed on the
molecular level as many small
vortexes of energy with vast spaces
in between. At this level, the very
idea of "boundary" loses meaning,
the "resistance" shifts, perhaps
disappears!
Contact work engenders such
perceptual shifts; to integrate them
requires a safe environment where
we can learn to listen to and trust
our bodily experience without fear or
self-judgment. Recently, my learning
process has included the ReParen-
ting'm work of Constance Abbott.
Body-Mind Centering taught me that
support precedes movement.
ReParenting encourages people not
only to understand and feel what
messages we needed and deserved to
receive from our families at different
stages in our development, but to
create situations in our adult lives
which can provide the support we
missed then and need now. It is, in
some ways, a reframing process: we
learn to look at our experience dif-
ferently and can then choose to act
differently, to not perpetuate pain.
Contact Improvisation, Body-Mind
Centering and other body-based
educational and therapeutic modes
take us beyond a mental reframing
into the physical experience of how
messages-both past and current-
are encoded in our bodies. When we
can feel movement patterns, we can
allow them to dissolve on a cellular
level, a tissue level, and reclaim the
power of active choice, balanced by
receptive flow, in our movement and
our lives.
In last winter's classes, I had
created permission for my students
and myself to follow inner desires, to
enjoy movement, to meet resistance.
But I hadn't known how to establish
enough safety for all of us to hang
out at the edge of our comfort zones
and to let movement happen from
that edge.
For many people, the mere fact of
participating in a group is unsafe.
Groups are often places where our
bodily experience must be repressed
or denied. As the main model for
group interaction in our society, the
nuclear family provides a setting-
echoed in schools, workplaces, and
community groups-where members
are often ignored, stifled or actively
abused. We have few models for get-
ting our individual needs met while

Title: Hier - Visibility
Text:
Let me see. I gather egalitarianism
and hierarchy are opposed in the title
of Cynthia Novack's columns in the last
"Still Moving" section ["Egalitarianism
and Hierarchy in Contact Improvisa-
tion,'' CQ Vol. XIII no. 3]. I fear a trip
has been laid on us by some free-
associating dance critic who once
described CI as more democratic than
other dance forms. I sort of remember
that line getting picked up by subse-
quent reporters-freecwheeling, dance
for folk, etc., that kind of image aris-
ing uncensored, unexamined and
perhaps unverified. In fact, until
Novack questioned me recently, I don't
recall any of the many dance writers
asking about this point.
Egalitarianism resulted in democracy,
our 'form' of government. This was op-
posed to monarchy-Geo Washington
was offered the monarchy for the states
of America, I once learned. So that sort
of hierarchy was avoided by democratic
government. But a hierarchy, a tern~
porary one, is what we use to run the
country.
I believe I agree with Dumont's thesis.
Agreeing on values creates constraints
on individual directions. And humans
are a communicating animal-we get
jerked out of our path by far more sub-
tle events than agreeing on values.
Sometimes for good, sometimes for ill.
A pause, a glance will do it.
I have noticed that hierarchies are
noticed by those outside them. This sug-
gests that those who make them up are
to some degree ignorant of that fact, or
even that they are projected on a group,
or faction, or gathering, or team, or
committee by someone who perceives
the association as hier-. Or rather,
higher.
Now no one in these stories is dead;
Zimmer, Elias, Ryan, Harwqod or
myself; it would be possible to ask some
direct questions of all of us. For in-
stance, who organized the situation
Zimmer attended? I'll bet Ryan had a
hand in it. Harwood and Ryan are both
movers and shakers in the Canadian
Contact Improv. scene and it seems to
me no Contact scene could exist without
deep bonds existing-I mean people
must enjoy dancing together in order to
have it survive for over a decade. Zim-
mer probably wasn't the only beginner
who wanted to whet their skills on those
two, and probably not the only one to
emotionally defer to their skills.
Elias says there was definitely a sense
of in-group and out-group at the Cur-
rent Exchange gathering [in Vancouver,
B.C., summer 1979]. I can vouch that
there was such a situation. The in-group
consisted of any one who had a long
association with the idea of CI and had
toured and/or taught with the others.
The out-group were in such a group for
the first time. They were a bit at sea.
They didn't know how to act and since
there are no rules as such, no one told
them. The nice things about rules,
schedules, etc. is that they limit the
number of choices one has to make. If
one may act any old way, a bewilder-
ing situation may exist. Those who
weren't bewildered were in. Those who
were bewildered saw themselves as out.
If Current Exchange was elitist, it was
only in the sense that the entire U.S. and
Canada was not invited. In fact, living
conditions restricted the size. Word was
quietly put out to a few people who told
a few other people. A letter of intent
from participants was required to insure
they had their own reason for using the
facility (Western Front
Lodge/ gallery I studio/ video) and that
their reason resonated with the facility
and harmonized in practical ways with
the rest. Every one of us paid for the
rent of Western Front and pitched in for
food, cooking and cleaning up.
I fear that the article, in using these
two examples, will give elitism a bad
name. Surely just being a small group
or being buddies is not cause to bring
out such a big gun. To be elite is to hold
some plum and restrict its dispersal. To
use this word to criticize those who go
to the trouble of organizing classes or
who attempt to specialize and concen-
trate is to disparage a kind of grass roots
community work.
Zimmer and Elias will be amused to
learn that they have been placed in an
elite, at the top of a hierarchy, recent-
ly. In Berlin at the 4th annual Contact
Conference (they decided to drop the
word 'improvisation', to my despair).
A European delegate asked if all Euro-
peans could do with Contact was repeat
what the first generation had done. So
it goes. Zimmer and Elias are, to
Europe, first generation contactors.
And this is an example of a hierarchy
being perceived from without.
Truth be told, CI is a dance form. It
does have and, as far as I am concern-
ed, teach certain values; mostly to do
with physical safety.
CI has always abounded in logical
contradictions, foremost to do with im-
provisation. If improvisation springs
out of each moment in each individual,
then how to get people to improvise-
to discover their own initiative? And I
point this out in classes-this cannot be
taught, but it can be learned. I can help
with the physical part. I can provide
useful (to me, at least) images and
meditations. I can point out glaring er-
rors in partnering. I can't know how so-
meone feels or protect them from their
insecurity, fear, dislikes, associations,
boredom, or their elation, warmth,
sense of achievement, for that matter.
Contact Improvisation deals with
gravity, momentum, human bodies, etc.
Humans form or perceive hierarchies.
It is egalitarian. The folk who aren't in
Contact Improvisation, either don't
know about it or choose not to do it.
To pick at words just a bit more, Con-
tact Improvisation could not have "em-
braced values of individualism, equali-
ty, and anti-hierarchical relationships,''
because CI cannot do anything. It is
something to be done.
And in Dumont's remark some
strange loose ends, which perhaps
should be brought to the attention of the
U.S. government and of course, its
boss, the people: "If, in effect, the
whole of humanity is deemed present in
each man, then each man should be free
and all men are equal. By contrast, as
soon as a collective end is adopted by
several men, their liberty is limited and
their equality is brought into question."
So apparently even a government
formed on values such as freedom and
equality will trample on freedom and
equality. How embarassing. Yet even
such an experiment in good intentions
is of some interest, compared to the in-
tentions of other governments, then and
now. If liberty and equality are chosen,
then at the moment of choice, they ex-
ist. What happens the next moment is
something for all of us, anthropologists
especially, to ponder. *

Title: "They Came They Saw They Did a Little Shopping": Berlin
Text:
On Saturday afternoon August 20, 1977, some thirty participants and teachers of FOCUS 8/77 gathered
to talk about the Politics of Contact. The issue was as much one of defining the question or concern as it was coming
up with an answer. The discussion began with a minimal definition of politics: awareness of and concern for the
power relationships in a given interaction or situation, particularly those relationships which are unacknowledged.
or assumed and unquestioned. From this beginning the discussion was wide-ranging, spirited and largely unstructured.
Going back over a ta pc-recording of the seminar a month later, I have selected out and arranged (without
regard to original sequence) representative and provocative comments to share with the larger contact community.
To my knowledge this discussion was the first attempt to look at our work from this perspective and clearly it is only
one small step, but an important one. In retrospect, I saw our talk centering around two issues.· The first was seldom
defined as a focus but kept surfacing in people's comments: what kind of needs are filled by contact improvisation'?
Consuelo: I was interested in figuring out why it's come down that because of privilege like the $125
privilege and the class background privilege, why it is that this environment has developed around
contact; but I don't see that contact itself is this white cultural kind of ...
John: I'm not sure I agree with that, for one thing it's demonstrating the needs ... contact like anything
else is fulfilling certain needs.
Eleva: That's what I was going to say earlier, perhaps it's the white middle class that needs to get in touch
with their bodies.
Tom: What I see it gets down to is am I willing to go into the world receptively and attentively to what's
happening around me and to be in touch with my needs in a particular situation and other people's
needs. I really think it is something about the reason we're here is because we need to be here, else
we wouldn't be here, to learn whatever we're getting from this, and I see it very much in spiritual terms ...
this group of people is here to get what we're getting and I think a lot of people don't need it or are
doing it in another form.
Elizabeth: The same kinds of things that happen in contact are things that I think have happened to other
kinds of people in other situations, like in work situations where men do heavy physical work together
and might have to use their bodies in the same kind of cooperation and same kind of sensitivity to each
other ... but different than a dance situation ... which comes with a different kind of awareness.
Broni: Its purpose is different too.
Mark: This may relate to why this kind of event is strictly one ethnic group or one social class. I'm con-
cerned in society all over the country how it seems there's a great gap between this kind of situation
of workshops and focusing on a specific kind of dance and what I would call the masses ... their
desire to move and to socialize and be part of something which is being generally exploited. For
those people who are not coming to studio spaces and being part of something, the whole word dance
means to them Friday night and swallowing a six pack of beer and going to a bar or disco; I think
it's exploitative and I really feel there's a gap between that space and this space and it's really tough
to breach.
jerry: Contact has a lot in common with folk art and we are a folk ... we invent it as we go along, we
make it out of what we've got and the fact that what we've got is a college education, and money,
and attractive healthy bodies, and good teeth, you know, is different from having a bunch of ma-
hogany trees and a couple of rocks ... Contact improvisation has roots in dance, it was found by
dancers, and it has gone away from being a dance thing; it is a movement form. There are people
here who are not primarily dancers and the form is reaching out toward those people the way some
people seem to think we should be reaching out toward different classes of society or different
ethnic groups.
Mark: I feel that there are some aspects of this kind of dance that are slightly different than any kind of
particular outlet that supplies the needs for any particular ethnic group. I really feel that there are
some aspects of contact that are evolutionary .. I can't think, unless somebody can fill the space, of
other kinds of dance in the past which have been this free with sharing and this much touch and con-
nections .. I think this kind of dance is more significant in specific kinds of problems, like sexual
politics, for example, men dancing with men ... and even in the sense that it doesn't rely upon other
forms like music - goes right to an essence or centering ... This form of dance crosses a few more
bridges than others have.
Consuelo: You mean in the sense that it is kind of like a future vision of how people can relate to each
other in terms of sensitivity and activity?
Jon: In terms of sexual politics we're still dealing with one on one, two people getting together, and contact
gives you metaphors for expanding that to three or four or ten or twenty or whatever and that should
be explored too. ·
Keriac: Watching a ballet that gets into these boy.girl things, I don't get much metaphor for my life from
those; whereas I really find the material in contact, the interpersenal stuff that's happening in contact,
is a really useful sophisticated metaphor for what I'm experiencing. ·
Consuelo: Right now I feel really committed to art for change. It's really not enough to do a contact
performance for me, it really isn't. I feel like I want to know more what's going to come out and
deliver a message; and I don't mean just whatever message is there but I mean pretty specific messages.
Kris: There's something about pure energy that gets exchanged between people, we become something
of everything we are around, and when I see a performance I become those performers; and it means
a lot to me and it's the strongest and most pure learning experience I have and it's devoid of content.
It's not statements.
Consuelo: Well, that sounds like a pretty powerful statement.
I see that most of these needs in relation to contact have to do with the desire to break down the uneven
power of the various roles that people assume in relating to one another, be it male to male, dancer to nondancer,
or performer to audience. Contact improvisation as a political process can thus be seen as a means for bringing
people together in a way that prevents or at least discourages the assumption of roles and inequalities of power
which roles so often establish. There seemed to be agreement that, on an immediate personal level, contact achieved
this aim if the integrity of the physical form was respected.
The second issue of the discussion seemed to center around the kind of relationship the contact community
and the contact form is establishing with the larger society. Does and will this relationship maintain the same freedom
from inequalities in power and thus allow all people access to the vital (role-less?) movement relationships which are
contact improvisation?
Karen: The way to deal with it is to work on both levels - one is on the normal ground level of literally
dealing, believing that change takes place and revolution takes place within my own body first and
then at the same time being aware of where my body is: is it in the studio, in Cat's Paw, and that
door is closed unless I have $125, and then what do I do about that; and I think there are two dif-
ferent issues and both are necessary.
Brent: But we made this experience available for ourselves ... at least I did.
Karen: Because it is within your program in life to be able to do that. We're talking about a whole part
of the world where it isn't part of the program - it's not there ... so is art going to be something
we're talking about, an eclectic thing that stays where it is, or can this particular art form go out
because it doesn't have to have all that professional dilettantism that other forms have. Can it just
be a way of reaching people on another basis?
Laurie: Not right now.
john: This is a white middle class trip and other people out of that might not necessarily want to have it.
Laurie: And they might and they can't because they can't afford to.
John: That's not true.
Laurie: If one person wants to and can't ...
John: There have been set up free situations for people to study this and it is only taken by white upper
class people. '
Ernie: Sometimes it becomes a real trip that we are laying on them because we don't have the sensitivity
to know what they need.
Mark: What is the balance between being crusaders for contact and making it an available form for those
that are interested?
John: It is a manifestation I think in many ways of class differences and therefore class problems that we
should deal with; solutions are tough.
Evelyn: Most of the arts are a social ... I mean there's a certain class of people that do them. For a long
time they were a very elitest thing.
Ernie: But is it elitist? That word really blows my mind cause it's a power term. It assumes that if we
develop a dance form, it is automatically elitist. It's a dance form! ... something that came out of
our culture. Our culture may be elitist in a lot of ways - money and social structures generally, but
that doesn't mean the dance form is elitist.
Laurie: But it reflects the society.
Karen: I am forever grateful in one way, in an aesthetic sense, and in other ways, for things that have come
out of formalized, in a sense elitist, art forms and I value them. Then I hear what we're saying on the
other side. Now is there room for both ways to be?
Keriac: If you are thinking of contact as a folk art and experiencing it, it is quite a different setup than if
you are thinking of it as a performing art or a spectator thing. Like Karen was talking about, how can
we have both of these things, that they both enrich our lives? I think that it is facetious to say that
it is a folk art so that we can all rest our minds about that, you know, that we don't have to be con-
cerned about ... that we're clean; this is a folk art, it's ok. One can use contact lots of other ways -
the relative morality, the rightness or wrongness or whether it fits into your value system should be
examined.
Ernie: If you take something like contact ... and you can make it into where you're more sensitive to
life in general, the balances and flux of life in general, then it becomes evolutionary; but if you take
it and it becomes another package, then that's what it is, another package.
Some questions arc asked. concerns expressed and a dialogue begins. I hope the excerpts above may have
provoked thoughts in you and that you will share them with others. It is part of the dance. I hope that l have not
distorted too much the meaning of what people said by taking comments out of context or order. And in reading,
please realize the text above is in some sense my interpretation, my reflection, my recreation of what took place.
You had to be there. . . ·
------fl------
BYRON BROWN is one of the founding members of Mangrove and a member of the Bay Area Contact Coalition who
sponsored Focus: 8/77. He lives and teaches contact in San Francisco, California.

Title: Contact Jam: A Definition
Text:
Contact Improvisation is a way for people to come together and interact on a purely physical
level. Fostering a healthy interaction is the important concern.
In coming to a dance one must be ready to engage in a constant effort to focus on the physical
sensations of weighted movement, balance and stillness. It is not the issue to identify through any
conscious thought process what the sensations are; you need not know "what physical sensations
you are experiencing," you must know how to focus with constant effort. It is. the strength and purity
of this effort which will foster a healthy interaction in dancing with another.
The simplicity of the form Contact Improvisation is a gift. Its value is that it Is A Way for you and
I to dance together. To befriend the forces of gravity and momentum is to dance with a sense of humor
and constant humility, is to discover one's being self, is to discover true communion.
The essence of this dancing is the concentration and focus one brings as a dancer, it is only through
this constant effort that our dancing will continue to be.
Four laws of ecology: "(1) everything is connected to everything else;
(2) everything must go somewhere;
(3) nature knows best; and
(4) there is no such thing as a free lunch."
Barry Commoner in The Closing Circle,
A. Knopf, New York, 1971, p. 18.

Title: Basic
Text:
By arranging and rebalancing our scrutiny and
our relaxation of focus in our daily routine we
find ways to our appropriate redemptions. The
constant prayer that leads the pilgrim, Saint
Therese's "little way", the yogi's systems of
breathing, and the mover's attention to the body
as it washes, waits for the bus, cleans out the
catbox or ties a shoelace are among ways we
focus our being towards whatever unexpectable
or hoped-for visionary experience waits grace-
fully for us.
Verbal languages and body languages both pre-
sent regions of articulation, regions of common
understanding, and regions of the unknown. By
looking at "what we know" we approach the fas-
cinating places of "the unknown". Historically,
Contact Improvisation began with everything un-
known and in the recent handful of years, a body
of knowledge, perhaps a grammar of words and
motions, has been evolving. We know we belong
to the same tribe because we understand each
other; we share a context.
flexibility active bounce round robin
circle breath play partner
attention gravity momentum pathways
floor honest dialogue wave
trust weight float stillness
skeleton mood glide interfacing
contact rise skin center
(This example is a random selection from lists of
"words related to Contact improvisation" made
during a writing seminar led by Nancy Stark Smith
in Seattle, January 1979.)
By now, hundreds and hundreds of people have
had some exposure to the form and its language,
through classes, workshops, performances, re-
views, magazines, and photographs. People from
all walks of life have attempted to describe, ana-
lyze, teach Contact in terms of their own vocab-
ularies, which range from the scientifically
spare to the wildly rhapsodic. Meeting changes
and development within the practice of the form
and colliding, assimilating, and crossing with
words from other contexts, the language of Con-
tact Improvisation attempts to stay clear, direct,
and as immediate as the movement itself.
The very obvious and the very subtle are al-
ways present in any utterance, pose, or figura-
tion. Understanding the shapes and shades of
meaning and of momentum is as easy and as dif -
ficult as understanding music or the weather.
Embodying a concept may or may not use words
before, during, and/ or after; when we seek
discourse, the universe of words enters the pic-
ture. While a woman rolls in a wavelike motion
across the floor, another woman waves to her,
waving her hand. - (Homonym phenomenon.)
During "the stand", a condition of vertical
rest, in which the skeleton is balanced so the
muscles don't have to work to hold the body up,
small adjustments and rebalancings were noted
to go on involuntarily. When the accumulating
jiggles and twitches were seen to be a continuity,
there had to be something to call it, and it is
"the small dance". This happened in the old days.
Also in the old days, so many experimental move-
ments were attempted that they were. given num-
bers. These days the only one that is called by
its number is "the 58". "58" is a vault pivoting
off the partner's thighs, around hip-to-hip, rol-
ling over an arc across the partner's back, fi-
nally rolling off into the air or someplace else.
Influx and innovation occur in oi.tr lingo through
borrowings like aikido rolls, t' ai chi stepping;
forward rolls; from physics and metaphysics we
adapt and adopt referent points like counterbal-
ance, chakra, yoga asanas, field .energies, ma.g-
netism. Innovative word-invention can produce
terms immediately understandable, for example,
Simone Forti's use of "artsport" soon swept the
Contact village and one feels again how perfect
a word it is coming upon the ungainly "sportart"
in a newspaper clipping. Other terms like "blotto
dance" never quite caught on. "Finger ouija"
may or may not be current.
Obviously Contact's language functions among
practitioners-only groups, and in mixed groups
which include non-contactors. In the former case,
assumptions are frequently taken for granted,
based on common experience. Just as you can
tell at once if your partner is really in kinetic
dialogue with you, when verbal conversation flows
the words are subsidiary to the moment, suppor--
tive of the meaning. In the case of the latter,
often contactors find ourselves making wild anal-
ogies with rock-climbing or talus-running (which
we may not have done a whole lot of ourselves),
trying to clarify concepts without having to de-
monstrate at cocktails just what a 58 is. When
we are faced with a reporter, our mother, a
dance teacher, a baseball fan, or a child who
sees us doing it in the park, what words do we
call up? At the best of these moments the prin-
ciples that live within our process emerge mo-
mentarily, and some of the phrases stay around.
Repeating definitions, describing the same mo-
ment several times, feeding our words and ges-
tures into the common experience keeps refining
and redefining and refinding the same· old gravity
and change.

(Where two frames of reference cross, forming
four corners, linear transmissions fan out to-
wards new forms in old formats, and variant con-
ditions, as "from visceral to visual", verbal to
ideogrammatic .)
The frame of reference of transmission at its
clearest is in the actual movement when mind and
body play with each other.'retting go. Sometimes
after a duet we have no words because the exper-
ience was its own verb, its own noun. Art in
teaching, healing, presentation relies upon arti-
culation of the parts, knowing the anatomy, the
syntax. As we come to know the form we learn
its languages, and we change and it changes and
we keep finding the known.and the unknown, like
the subtle and the obvious, in every gesture and
utterance. It will stay like this and keep on going.
Will you come for it? What are the wild waves
saying?
Questions for discussion.
1. How can an axis function as an axiom, an
axiom as an axis?
2. Do you say: Do it this way OR This is how
we do it?
3. Do you say: Let's have/make/do some
Contact Improvisation?
L.. Do you ever hear or use words in Con~act
Imp situations which you don't understand?
Do you ask what they mean?
5. Do you ever stand under your partner?
6. What one word or phrase in the Contact lm-
proVisation common usage (or not so common)
needs most attention now?
7. What movement most needs a name?
8. Can you tell a very brief story using all the
words in Example 1? ls it easier to rear-
range the order? Is alphabetical order more
yielding or more resistant to you?
9. In this drawing, what is happening? How can
you relate it to the other drawing (Example
2)? ls c_ontinuity or framing the more obvi-
ous or the more subtle in each?
10. How would you explain 58 to your mother?
How would you explain the contact point to
a spy-novel writer?

Title: Harbin
Text:
The first CALIFORNIA HARBIN HOT SPRINGS CONTACT JAM was real good.
I hod a nice time. A lot of people come from where /live-the Bay Area-but some from
Chico, one from Boulder and a few from other West Coast towns.
Being a newcomer to the contact community, I felt unfamiliar with what a jam
was supposed to be. You know, I hod read some earlier issues of CQ, taken a couple
classes from N. S. Smith at Wesleyan U., even did some Cl in NYC at PS122. But, going
away for a long weekend with complete strangers to bathe in hot pools and dance didn't
exactly make me feel at home, or at ease.
What was the purpose of a jam, besides a reunion for those who hod already been
practicing the form for awhile? I could tell there were some of us who were new to this
kind of situation and didn't know precisely what was going on. This initial awkward
time reminded me of my first high school dance.
About everyone agreed that music and dance should be present (but separate
some of the time) during the weekend. A lot of us, including myself, were interested in
not setting particular times for dancing and drumming or even bedtime. Someone re-
marked that the time might be felt organically.
At first, not a lot of time was spent collectively breathing or arriving. "Plunging
in" is what seemed to be the desire of many. Maybe the hot springs pools provided the
springboard for this desire. I couldn't join the flow, though, because plunging in is a
fear of mine. I needed to toke time to sit and think and tune into myself for what I
wanted from this jam.
We were in a completely new world at Harbin, a rustic 7000 mile woodland,
mountainous tree-lined areas volleying and rising oil around our enclosed dance shelter.
A small brook ran by with clear water from the Napa Valley (wine country here in
California). But with oil that beautiful natural environs, it was still troubling to me not
knowing the jam boundaries. What were the rules of the game, as they soy? I sow possi-
bilities in group sex, a homosexual and heterosexual couples' scene, raucous contact,
soft-eye dancing, rolling and breathing.
All this stuff I felt Friday night or so. Then, on Saturday morning, things opened
up. Some of the senior members of the group taught half-hour mini-courses in Contoct-
esque basics and new discoveries. I went up to the pools in the afternoon. It wosn 't so
bod there. It was softer and quieter than in the dance shelter. Hazy and lazy, strong
and light, mole and female, folks were just chatting and healing. Four of us novice con·
tocters huddled our arms together in the pool and floated around like a spinning wheel.
We talked about what we sow Friday night. To my surprise, we shored a lot of common
observations. Then, we steamed in the hottest tub. We walked out ofter\·ords, my
bones felt heavy and my muscles suspended around my bones.
On Saturday night, .the jam got together in a circle to discuss the moi•ement of
the weekend. While people talked, someone tossed small coloriul ploybolls bock and
forth in the circle. It looked like a game of marbles. You would toss a boll into the
center and someone would try to knock yours out of the center and onto the periphery.
Then, I forget who rolled herself into the center as a human marble. People giggled and
rolled her around. Others joined her. That beautiful stock of 64 pillows by the \·all
become the next marbles, and a huge and monstrous pillow fight ensued. Finale: a dive
bombing affair.
Pillow rumble, it was real good. A lot of heavy stuff. Straight, bold and big
strides over obstacles into the pile of tossed pillows. The rest of the weekend was fun.
I think we, as a group of disparate individuals, discoi·ered our challenge: a common
ground. I think we also discovered a commitment: on organic message. To me, it was
on unfurling of the foll, a movement outward and down across the floor. As I spoke
with someone on Sunday afternoon on the trail bock from our lost dip in the pool, I
felt a return.
Andrew Clibanoff

Title: Contact
Authors: Improvisation Is ... Excerpts from class flyers
Text:
Accept your limits. I ask that students allow themselves the permission to realize their limitations.
I also encourage the sudden stretch beyond limitation. To see within this language the existence of
a subtle yet expansive definition of the word 'risk'. "Isn't that very risky?" asked a student looking
up at a friend pivoting in the valley between neck and shoulder of her partner. I believe this work
and other explorations compatible with Contact always involve the element of risk, whether we are
rolling along air-born arcs or standing still.
As flow does not mean slow, receptivity needn't be measured by passivity. 'Listening' is one of my
favorite words in describing the force behind transition.
Attention needs to wander to stay interested. In the teacher, your partner, yourself. Re-circulate.
Hearing Robert Creely opinionate that the full human attention is there for forty minutes.
The concern for rhythm and balance of class time. Developing trust in the quiet of before and after-
images. The forms of students moving, trucks on the freeway, the teacher's words measured and heard
by breath, inter-relate and create a whole entity.
The class assists a teacher in locating his or her placement between the skills of observance and verbal-
ization. Besides the basic sense of too much or not enough (alternately, I've been told by students
how there is excessive technical input or a frustration due to a casual and modest directive), we learn
to use the word if it fits. Of course there is still much more to say.
In one of his first introductory classes, asking: "ls the contact point the tension between trust and
responsibility?" In agreement - yes, Danny, there seems to be many levels of lifting experience.
Dancing well with new students is the most advanced part of my learning.

Title: Contact Class Titles & Descriptions
Text:
Welcome. Yes; you're in the right place. The Contact Newsletter has moved on to become the
Contact Quarterly - a publication put out voluntarily by Free Association four times a year (seasonally).
Free Association isn't an official name for those of us behind the Quarterly, but a term that catches the
spirit of our collaboration. Our personnel shifts with each issue depending on (1) which coast is hosting the
production, and (2) the availability and interest of local contacters for work on the production.
Our common center is a working and experiential knowledge of Contact Improvisation. So far,
everyone who has 'freely associated' on any of the Newsletter/Quarterly publications has had some exper-
ience with this new, now almost five-year-old, dance-movement-meditation-art-sport-event-piece. On that
basic ground we 'stand', and from that stand we swing out - into our overlapping worlds to collect material
and enthusiasm to channel back through the center and out as far as it travels. Arriving safely and with news.
Contact is interface. And though there are only certain faces you've seen before, there are many
more where they came from. Parallel transparencies. Two people inventing electricity within days of each
other on opposite sides of the globe. Coincidence? Yes, Co-Incidence. And in a likewise but less dramatic
manner, we find more of each other every day.
Contact Improvisation has the unique quality of being believed - whether admired, respected,
scorned, berated, inflated or ignored. Yes real time. Yes real bodies. Yes real people. This particular
credibility allows Contact Improvisation and those involved in it, to run tangent to many worlds - relating
deeply in to those worlds without either becoming distracted or dilute. In fact, the communication which we
continue to develop among ourselves and articulate in our dancing serves us well outside our immediate
numbers. It is what creates our access to the unfamiliar faces, the rapidly surfacing and the as-yet unsurfaced
numbers of people who are working with the material of their lives in just such a direct manner as we attempt
in our teaching, performing and writing of Contact Improvisation.
We 'stand' together at the ring of a watering hole; our weight brings the water up, our bodies,
the weight down.

Title: Berlin Contact Conference, 1988
Text:
About eighty five people came from
Europe and the U.S. to take part in the
Fourth European Contact Teachers Con-
ference in Berlin, W. Germany from June
8-13, 1988.
About a year ago, the Tanzfabrik (literal-
ly, "Dance Factory") was asked to par-
ticipate in "Werkstatt Tanz: Issues for the
Nineties" as Berlin is the European City of
Culture for 1988. DIETER HEITKAMP,
BRUNO STEFANONI and BOB REASE col-
lectively organized this conference with a
theme of 'New Influences and Crossovers'.
"Werkstatt Tanz: Issues for the Nineties"
was organized around a theme of artistic ex-
change and some of the events of the con-
ference were open to the public.
June 8th and 9th were days for registration
and open dancing as well as reunions with
friends, and acquainting oneself with parts
of Berlin. Most people had arrived by the
evening of Thursday 9th for an official
welcoming and introductions at the new
studio at Tanzfabrik. One studio had been
put aside as a 'Video Cafe' and quiet room
where, throughout the conference, videos
of contact-related work were being shown
informally.
Friday 10th June began with OPEN JAMS
in three studios at the Tanzfabrik. On Friday
afternoon, NANCY STARK SMITH and
ROBIN FELD led two separate
WORKSHOPS-"Developing the Form"
and "Contact and Martial Dance."
On Saturday afternoon, ISHMAEL
HOUSTON-JONES led a workshop on the
Politics of dancing, while PAULINE DE
GROOT led one on improvised dance and
music.
On Friday and Saturday evening after din-
ner, there were two PANEL DISCUSSIONS.
The topicfor Friday was 'Teaching' and Nan-
cy Stark Smith moderated, assisted by Steve
Paxton [see excerpts from this discussion in
this Newsletter]. People on the panel includ-
ed ROBIN FELD, BOB REASE, LOUISE
RICHARDS, BRUNO STEFANONI, BERND
KAMMERER, and GILA ROGERS. The
discussion looked at questions in teaching
such as the definition of a teacher, language
and Contact, sexuality and aggression within
sessions, and Contact in Therapy. Bernd
spoke of his difficulties in the translation from
English into German, of the concepts and
practice of Contact. He had learnt Contact
in English and was teaching it in German.
Bernd was voicing an experience of teaching
which must be common to all those teachers
of Contact for whom English is not their first
spoken language. It was added that it helps
to use language which is part of the lives of
the people being taught, to teach concepts
of Contact in ways which will make it ac-
cessible for them.
Steve Paxton said that his first concern
when teaching Contact was how to teach it
without people hurting themselves. Robin
Feld described how she uses the breath to
encourage the release· and flow of weight in
her teaching. Using imagery such as melting,
softening and folding at the joints all helps
to encourage a safe physical environment for
doing Contact. Louise, who teaches Contact
with Kevin Finnan in high security prisons,
said that changing from a dispersed to a
focussed activity can also prevent injury in
a session.
The question "what are you teaching
when you are teaching Contact?" was link-
ed with finding a definition of a teacher.
STEVE BATTS spoke of sharing an investiga-
tion with his students. He directs but may
not know the outcome of the activity. He
brought up the element of improvising in
teaching, so that possibilities may be ex-
plored by teacher and learner together.
"What about feeling and emotion in Con-
tact?" This brought up some important
issues. Steve Paxton talked about how emo-
tion may or may not be acknowledged in
dance. He spoke of how Contact arose in
a dance context, within which people such
as Martha Graham and Jose Limon were
dealing with emotion, and making it into
form. Paxton was drawn to Merce Cunn-
ingham, because Cunningham's dancing
ethic was more abstract and he dealt with
shape, form, space and time-the physics of
dancing. This was more intellectual and
there was less drama, less expression of emo-
tions. In physics there is gravity, momentum,
shape, angles and as physics is present in
dancing, so are the emotions, "but we don't
know how to deal with it, teach it, make it
into a form." This was difficult for Kevin Fin-
nan who explained that he taught Contact
to criminals who have killed children and
adults, including their relations, and these
'students' learn Contact and talk about it
afterwards. I think there was some confusion
here between finding forms for emotional ex-
pression in daily life, and finding emotional
forms for dance, although the distinction can
sometimes be difficult. Contact in therapy
was an issue which was also discussed, and
Gila Rogers, a dancer who is also a
psychotherapist, explained how she combin-
ed Developmental work with Contact in her
treatment of emotionally disturbed people
and how effective Contact can be in her
work generally.
On the following evening, the topic for the
panel discussion was 'Performing
Contact-Working with Personal Material'.
Steve Paxton moderated, assisted by Nan-
cy Stark Smith. The discussion began with
an infqrmal jam for the panel who were
PAULINE DE GROOT, LAURIE BOOTH,
BOB REASE, DIETER HEITKAMP,
ISHMAEL HOUSTON-JONES, MARK TOM-
PKINS and JAAP KLEVERING. When the
dancing had subsided, some people found
seats to sit on, while others continued im-
provising while the discussion took place.
After about an hour, there was a break and
the panel rearranged their chairs closer to
the audience and remained seated. Steve
began by asking each person on the panel
to say a little about themselves, and their
work. He also asked them whether they had
danced in a Broadway show or musical,
which had run for more than three nights,
or if they had danced on a boat, and whether
they performed set material or improvised
material. I was occupied with taping the
discussion and taking photos so my notes are
scarce. However, I have down that Laurie
Booth was interested in aberrant behaviour
as movement in performance, describing
aberrant as marginalized or unusual activi-
ty. He recounted an incident which he was
witness to at the zoo that morning, where
a monkey had made history by imitating a
film cameraman to the point where the
monkey was making a film of everybody
looking at him inside his cage. (I think this
is what he meant, although the cameraman
may have given the monkey the equipment
to make a film). Ishmael had never danced
any set material, and Steve was alone in dan-
c~ng in a sh~w which repeated itself for many
nights running.
JORGEN TELLER asked whether im-
provisation can become a collection of anec-
dotes from learned forms. Steve replied, "Be
careful of what you're taught, every step
you've ever learned is stored in the body,
and pieces will emerge when you're least exJ
pecting it." There was a lot of discussion
around defining the form of Contact Im-
provisation. A definitive statement of Steve's:
"Forms exist to follow, but you're less than
human if you don't try to break them." This
panel discussion began at 8pm and was go-
ing strong at 11 :30pm when I left. There
were tapes made of it which would hopefully
be obtainable at the Tanzfabrik.
The NETWORKING COMMUNITY
MEETING began at lOam on Sunday mor-
ning, with sunshine streaming through the
window of the studio. We decided that the
next European Contact Teacher's Con-
ference would take place from the 10th-17th
August 1989 in Finland, and Jaap Klevering
and Jaana Turunen would be organizing it.
in Cyprus and Walter Weiler offered to
organize one for Zurich, Switzerland.
Dieter Heitkamp was interested in com-
piling a kind of journal to document
responses to and feelings about the con-
ference in Berlin. In the last part of the
meeting we all shared something of this with
the rest of the group. Here are some of the
things that were said:
How to begin dancing with strangers.
Was this a conference or a symposium.
The founders of Contact dance don't know
the definition of it.
The conference was part of Issues for the
Nineties and we spent most of the time
talking about the '60s and '70s.
At no time did anyone say OK that's what
Contact is.
To make a group at this conference to talk
about personal, social and political issues
surrounding Contact dancing.
That a large group of people should learn
how to listen to each other.
It is a political act to go and see how the
Berliners live instead of attending the
conference-this is as important as be-
ing 'in the stars'.
There is no personal communication after
such intimacy.
To create more opportunities for personal
work to develop.
The psychology of the outsider-a
celebration.
To sustain a network between conferences.
Wanting to have nothing to do with the 'hip-
py, pseudo cult' which Contact could
become and to keep Contact available
for all people.
The "BERLIN JAM" on Sunday afternoon
was an opportunity for open dancing among
people outside of the conference and those
in it, and new energy and faces meant reviv-
ed dancing, for me anyway. It was a
welcome change from the highly structured
events of the conference, and reminded me
of the two days open jamming before the
conference began. I enjoyed the Sunday
afternoon novelty of that jam and was glad
of the opportunity to dance with new
people.
That night was the party, and Dieter
transformed the biggest studio with some
spotlights and a sound system into a disco.
On Monday morning a group of us went
to a cafe together. At the Contact Network-
ing meeting Mark Tompkins suggested that
people get together and talk about the per-
sonal, social and political issues that they ex-
perienced in dance and particularly Contact
dance. It was a small group and there was
the chance to talk quite personally which
was a relief. The group was small enough for
some close personal communication to take
place and I feel that this is what the con-
ference, by virtue of its size, failed to pro-
vide for, except in this group and outside of
the structured ti me.
The PERFORMANCE MARATHON was
from 1 pm to 6pm that afternoon. This event
was open to the public and everyone paid
15 marks toward it for the Berliner Aids Hilfe.
In the first half there were solos, duets and
one or two group pieces. This half was quite
organized, in that there was a predetermin-
ed order to the pieces. There were im-
provisations and set pieces in this part of the
marathon, including new collaborations.
After the break, the space was basically open
except there was a structure which Pauline
ignored or forgotten as time w;nt by.
When one of the musicians left, sound
became the domain of the dancers who ac-
companied themselves from around the
space or within it, talking and singing, or us-
ing tapes or playing the percussion in-
struments that were available. The space was
nearly always pretty well full of activity and
there were one or two solos and at one point
there were about twenty people in the
space.
The marathon was the last organized event
of the conference, although most people
would be attending the PERFORMANCES of
STEVE PAXTON and LISA NELSON, and
LAURIE BOOTH that evening in another
part of Berlin. But it was the end of the con-
ference at the Tanzfabrik and so those of us
who were there sat in a circle together for
two minutes of silence to acknowledge an
ending with Dieter, Bob and Bruno.
I would like to finish with some quotes by
KERIAC from an article called "Politics and
Contact" in an old issue of CQ:
. whv was this form named Contact Im-
provisation and not Steve Paxton Technique?
In the entire modem dance world, every new
approach except Contact is based on a cult
of personality: Graham technique, Cun-
ningham technique, Hawkins technique,
etc . .. to me, that name is revolutionary-it
reflects a whole new value system in
dance. . I understand that Paxton was a
teacher at Bennington at the time he began
exploring Contact, and that his co-workers
were mostly students. And yet, if two peo-
ple try to do Contact while maintaining the
typical student-teacher relationship, I think
those two wouldn't end up doing much Con-
tact at all. Both the name and the form itself
assume that Contact is a collective creation
that is bigger than individuals. There is a let-
ting go of ego, and a letting go of traditional
role expectations, that is unprecedented in
dance.
.. Contact began with the progressive, anti-
elitist values of its inventors. But third and
fourth generation contacters, who may have
little or no contact with the originators, now
outnumber the originators as teachers of the
form. It's quite possible to teach someone
'Contact' in the physical dimension only,
without any conscious reference to values,
or even in relation to values that conflict with
the form. To me, it's important for teachers
of Contact to cultivate in themselves and in
their students a heightened awareness of the
political and spiritual richness of this form of
dance.
.. I think we in the Contact community
have a unique opportunity to foster the
revolutionary model that was generated by
the Contact originators. We can validate the
activities that do not conform to the tradi-
tional expectations, because our own ex-
perience in Contact has given us intimations
of another type of 'good quality perfor-
mance' . .. we can perceive performers as real
people in real time, making choices that have
physical results neither good nor bad, rather
than applauding 'stars' whose image would
be ruined by a 'mistake'."
[from "Politics and Contact," interview with
Keriac by Mark Pritchard, San Francisco
1979, CQ Vol. Vil no. 7. Fall 7987.]
JULIET SHELLEY lives and works in Oxford,
England and is a member of Jointwork Dance
Group.

Title: Teaching Contact Improvisation
Text:
This statement was submitted to
the Educational Policies Committee
of Hampshire College, Amherst, Mass.
on November 29, 1979.

Contact improvisation is a move-
ment technique. Though much young-
er than ballet or modern dance, it
proves to be as rich and dee~. It ei_n-
bodies a progression of physical skills
which can be used to train the begin-
ner as well as challenge the virtuoso.
Students of contact improvisation
acquire access to a large realm of
movement very quickly and begm to
make significant changes in their
movement patterns, strength, and sen-
sitivity within three or four classes.
This makes the technique particularly
desirable for the theater student and
non-dancer.

The skills acquired in contact im-
provisation are by no means limited
to the form itself. A deep understand-
ing of weight, movement flow, and use
of strength greatly aid anybody who
desires to study ballet, modern dance,
or other physical disciplines. The ex-
tensive exposure to the physical and
mental states involved in improvising
and discovering movement can help
choreographers in their attempts to
gather material for their set work.

Contact improvisation directly
strengthens one's presence. Just as
one can become aware of the eyes
seeing, the ears hearing, and the skin
feeling, one can become aware of the
mind sensing. Through practice of
this dance form one becomes able to
experience and observe the state of
one's nervous system particularly
when in an intimate physical relation-
ship with another. This spawns an
element of control over one's percep-
tual reality. This control and ability
to focus is training in developing pow-
er. Personal power and strength of
presence is essential in any performing
situation as well as in daily life.

Contact improvisation nurtures a
basic physical trust between two
people and among a group. The form
demands a care and consideration of
one's partner and towards this end
seeks to develop sensitivity and con-
fidence. This trust and the freedom
which ensues kindles a rich and fertile
environment for working creatively
with another person. Knowledge and
experience of this environment aids
in any situation where people are
working together, actors on stage
doing a scene, or dancers performing
a piece.

The working relationships which
develop in this form cross the bound-
aries created by sexual roles; men
dance with men, women with women,
and men with women alike. I do not
know of anv artistic discipline in
which non-~exual, deep, and honest
physical contact is explored with_ to-
tal equality relative to sex. In this
form women lift men as often as men
lift women. Women learn to exercise
a kind of strength which often has
never been encouraged, likewise men
learn to allow themselves a soft, re-
sponsive, and non-competitive posture.
It is a revelation to both partners that
a one hundred and eighty pound man
can be easily & completely supported
by a one hundred pound woman.
Again, the trust derived from freeing
the traditional sexual roles creates a
more comfortable and fluid atmos-
phere among any group of artists
seeking to work together.

Contact improvisation seems to be
of particular value for the college age
person. College students find them-
selves in an intense period of transi-
tion. They are coming to grips with
the image and reality of themselves
as adults. Thev are intently exploring
the psychological politics of sexual
relationships. This form offers them
a grounded, simple, and clear oppor-
tunity to interact deeply and honestly
with each other. It seems to serve as
a reference point or forum for expe-
riencing oneself in relationship with
others in an unthreatening environ-
ment and without the need to formu-
late consciouslv or to talk about what
is going on. The strongest evidence
for the emotional supportive value of
this work is the very real attraction
students have for this form. They
want to experiment and expand. This
form gives them the opportunity to
go ahead.

Title: A Bottle of Wine, a Cane, a Cloth
Text:
In the ancient fairy tales there is often a character walking in the woods where he meets a man (often named
Mercurius, one of the names of Hermes) who gives three gifts. These might include a bottle of wine that is never
empty, or a cane that will open any door, or a cloth that will heal any illness. A gift that is often given is the cloak
of invisibility. One of the images I often wear as I'm dancing is this cloak. I try not to interpret the image or figure
out how it applies to my dance, I simply wear it, and the dance changes.
In teaching Contact Improvisation, I have found images to be invaluable for getting at the soul of our dance.
It is possible to give physical corrections and teach techniques but I have found that it is the imagery that brings
down mountains and sets the oceans ablaze. The images are sometimes descriptive and sometimes prescriptive.
I will often flesh them out with a story or other images but they don't come with an explanation. Here is a list
of images, some that I have used in my own dancing and some that I have given in my classes:
- sleeping beauty after the kiss
- the sand in an hourglass
- sausages for bones
- an empty scale
- seeing through fish eyes
-Atlas after putting down the world
- think of yourself as a timeless piece of literature
-hunter after big game deep in the jungle and the lions
have just come into view
- bread rising and overflowing the bowl
- resplendent robes, jewels and crown of a king
- at the bottom of the exhale is when the lights go on
- pancake batter spreading as it's poured
- patina cracking and peeling off
- greenhouse for winter blossoms in the chest
- head and shoulders like a mop
-you have no forehead
- an old crone who has seen it all
- the reverence, standing in a grand cathedral with
sunlight streaming in
- flowing skirt, longgggg hair, dangling earrings, dozen
bracelets, emerald in bellybutton, tattoo of a rose on
the thigh
- filled with cooking garbanzo beans
- surprising thunder claps in the head
- set up house at the bottom of the exhale
- the view at the top of the inhale
- spaghetti as it's dropped into boiling water
-you have no arms or legs
- jellyfish in the joints
-the fall of the Roman Empire
- tumbleweed
- your spine is a pollywog (tadpole)
- your ribs are fingers
- pads of butter between each vertebra
- bird bones that are lighter than feathers
- a lover hand feeding you
- granite mountain with crags and ledges and trees
growing from rock
- a leaf in the wind
- mane of a lion whipping in the wind D

1. Is improvisation one thing or is it many different things?
2. Imagination and structure, where are we free?

Title: A Definition
Text:
Contact Improvisation is a duet art-sport currently receiving international attention by those insti-
tutions concerned with new departures in the forms of dance.

In the years since the inception of Contact Improvisation, in 1972, it has been adopted as perform-
ance mode by some 10 dance companies across the U.S., and used as a teaching technique by those
grass roots dance organizations, institutions and individuals concerned with investigation of d'ance
improvisation ephemera before the concerns of art aesthetics arise.
It is an activity related to familiar duet forms such as the embrace, wrestling, martial arts, and the
jitterbug, encompassing the range of movement from stillness to highly athletic. The exigencies of
the form dictate a mode of movement which is relaxed, constantly aware and prepared, and on-flow-
ing. As a basic focus, the dancers remain in physical touch, mutually supportive and innovative, me-
ditating upon the physical laws relating to their masses: gravity, momentum, inertia and friction.
They do not strive to achieve results but rather, to meet the constantly changing physical reality with
appropriate placement and energy.

Title: Some Considerations When Structuring an Improvisation -
Text:
Accept your limits. I ask that students allow themselves the permission to realize their limitations.
I also encourage the sudden stretch beyond limitation. To see within this language the existence of
a subtle yet expansive definition of the word 'risk'. "Isn't that very risky?" asked a student looking
up at a friend pivoting in the valley between neck and shoulder of her partner. I believe this work
and other explorations compatible with Contact always involve the element of risk, whether we are
rolling along air-born arcs or standing still.
As flow does not mean slow, receptivity needn't be measured by passivity. 'Listening' is one of my
favorite words in describing the force behind transition.
Attention needs to wander to stay interested. In the teacher, your partner, yourself. Re-circulate.
Hearing Robert Creely opinionate that the full human attention is there for forty minutes.
The concern for rhythm and balance of class time. Developing trust in the quiet of before and after-
images. The forms of students moving, trucks on the freeway, the teacher's words measured and heard
by breath, inter-relate and create a whole entity.
The class assists a teacher in locating his or her placement between the skills of observance and verbal-
ization. Besides the basic sense of too much or not enough (alternately, I've been told by students
how there is excessive technical input or a frustration due to a casual and modest directive), we learn
to use the word if it fits. Of course there is still much more to say.
In one of his first introductory classes, asking: "ls the contact point the tension between trust and
responsibility?" In agreement - yes, Danny, there seems to be many levels of lifting experience.
Dancing well with new students is the most advanced part of my learning.

Title: Final Notes on Improvisation
Text:
(A conversation with myself.)
Do you like to improvise?
Sometimes yes and sometimes no.
Why not?
Because I'm afraid that my body lacks ideas.
Why yes?
Because when the improvisation is over I discover that I've
enjoyed it and learned something as well. Improvising for me
is like eyeglasses for someone who doesn't see clearly.
Why are you afraid that your body lacks ideas?
What I mean to say is that when the improv begins, I do have
ideas, but feel too timid or incapable of carrying them
through; and that is why now I try to move not from
preconceived ideas, but rather in function of the present mo-
ment and the things around me.
What things?
First of all, the space-also, the other movers and objects.
While improvising, what do you find most stimulating?
I am rarely stimulated from the inside (maybe later on).
Specific places motivate me enormously, certain pieces of
music, occasionally themes and images, and also other
people. Maybe it's because I'm new to improvisation that I
need outside stimulation. I sometimes feel insecure because
I'm concerned with the quality of the final product, and with
improvisation you never know. On the other hand, I've
discovered how process can be as interesting as the final
product and is not necessarily complex. I've always had the
impression that discovery comes only by digging long and
deeply but, for now, I need first to look for those things close
to the surface and near to me. *
