tale into a story to be repeated
and retold for generations, a form
understood by every other cul-
ture."
We live in a culture that holds strict
definitions and value judgements about
what it sees as moving and not mov-
ing. With so much of daily motion
and perception dictated by task, func-
tion and particular examples of pro-
ductivity, movement at deeper levels
than external appearances are less
valued, ignored, and, at worst, unper-
ceived. How we are being seen by
others influences our self-image, pres-
ence and movements in the world. In
our classes, I feel that we were creat-
ing new layers of a collective story, a
body politic or body mythology.
Myths take shape in a ritualized space.
Several guest teachers (Dance and
Drama Therapist, Bronwyn Warren;
Feldenkrais teacher, Lawrence Gold-
farb; and Dance Therapist, Neala
Haze) were invited to present their
work during the semester. Neala
facilitated a session in Authentic
Movement. Having each student move
with eyes closed, "witnessed" by the
group, was a beautiful and evocative
ritual space. We were able to appreci-
ate the most subtly articulated move-
ments of each person, sensing and
referring to our own bodies for the
depth of response we gave one
another.
The experiential practice of the
course was augmented with readings
on dance, performance history, body
systems, developmental movement,
perception, sensory awareness, somatic
therapies, communication theories and
the use of touch in human experience.
Students kept journals and papers were
part of the requirements for academic
credit.
Many of the early classes brought
forth the awkwardness and anxiety
around physical touch between dis-
abled and non-disabled partnering. It
is very common for non-disabled
people to feel hesitant and fearful of
having physical contact with a person
in a wheelchair or one whose physical
form is shaped and moves differently
than their own. Often it is assumed
that the disabled person is brittle, in
pain or umesponsive to being touched.
In the class, students were strongly
encouraged to express their needs,
physical functioning and capabilities to
one another. This exchange of person-
al information helped to relax them
and elicit trust of an improvised and
collaborative spirit.
When encouraged to leave their
wheelchair or crutches through their
own movement or with assistance, the
initial experiences of many disabled
students (and of the non-disabled
assistant) ranged from extreme disori-
entation and vulnerability, to pleasure
and intense joy. A contained and safe
environment in which to express feel-
ings is very important in this context.
The process of dialoguing after danc-
ing allowed for us to speak from
changes in self-image and self-organi-
zation with increased awareness, sensi-
tivity and a mutual regard for one
another as moving, embodied beings in
the world
Our learning environment carried as
much influence as any of the specific
skills for falling and supporting
weight. Deane Juhan, in his book
Job's Body (Station Hill Press, 1987),
conveys a layer of this learning envi-
ronment from a physiological under-
standing: "The process is anything but
random or trial and error. It is highly
specific, and it is the periphery which
helps to organize the connections in
the central nervous system, not an
organized central nervous system
which reaches out to innervate the
periphery. It suggests that the use of
touch and sensation to modify our
experience of peripheral conditions
exerts an active influence upon the
organization of reflexes and body
image deep within the central nervous
system." Clearly, not all of the class
participants came with the same inten-
tions and interests. Most students,
both disabled and non-disabled, loved
the freedom to play and seek new
physical forms, to feel themselves
buoyant and resilient, fearless and
beautiful in their dance.
In the past year, I've been facilitat-
ing groups and workshops for profes-
sionals who work with or wish to
extend their practice to physically
disabled men and women. While
working with movement and somatic
practitioners, the focus is on how we
make contact with ourselves while
touching, supporting and moving with
someone who has a physical disability.
We look at ways to establish more of
a peer relationship. This process is a
risky one. Conventional and tradition-
al techniques are challenged, while
mutual dependency and the unknown
are brought into the relationship. This
is a process that medical science has
little familiarity with.
The impact of this course as ex-
pressed through responses from the
students and faculty of The Moving
Body strongly indicate a need and
desire for the continuance of this work
in university, clinical, community and
artistic settings. *
The Moving Body was videotaped and is
available to the public (see Dance Map in
this issue).

Title: Paths of Change: Notes on Contact Improvisation in an Institutional Setting
Text:
Accept your limits. I ask that students allow themselves the permission to realize their limitations.
I also encourage the sudden stretch beyond limitation. To see within this language the existence of
a subtle yet expansive definition of the word 'risk'. "Isn't that very risky?" asked a student looking
up at a friend pivoting in the valley between neck and shoulder of her partner. I believe this work
and other explorations compatible with Contact always involve the element of risk, whether we are
rolling along air-born arcs or standing still.
As flow does not mean slow, receptivity needn't be measured by passivity. 'Listening' is one of my
favorite words in describing the force behind transition.
Attention needs to wander to stay interested. In the teacher, your partner, yourself. Re-circulate.
Hearing Robert Creely opinionate that the full human attention is there for forty minutes.
The concern for rhythm and balance of class time. Developing trust in the quiet of before and after-
images. The forms of students moving, trucks on the freeway, the teacher's words measured and heard
by breath, inter-relate and create a whole entity.
The class assists a teacher in locating his or her placement between the skills of observance and verbal-
ization. Besides the basic sense of too much or not enough (alternately, I've been told by students
how there is excessive technical input or a frustration due to a casual and modest directive), we learn
to use the word if it fits. Of course there is still much more to say.
In one of his first introductory classes, asking: "ls the contact point the tension between trust and
responsibility?" In agreement - yes, Danny, there seems to be many levels of lifting experience.
Dancing well with new students is the most advanced part of my learning.

Title: Jumping Paradigms: A response to Aat Hougee
Text:
Nijinsky, rockets, platform shoes, Notre Dame, top-hats, the World Trade towers, every spire, every
pedestal, the pre-occupation of Western dance with leaps, the whole notion of Heaven.
Amidst mania for escape, (when did it begin?) from Earth's hold on us, Contact Improvisation springs
up and spreads love of the fall. Instead of the rebellion of blast-offs, there is a surrender of surfaces.
The lust for the "impossible," a moon-landing, a test-tube child, we replace with attention to the actual.
"Find out what the body does; not what you can make it do." The crusade to capture a There is aban-
doned, leaving us here, to fall, and roll and fly.
Christie Svane

Title: The Fountain at I.D.E.A.
Text:
The Fountain is a form for collective watching and reporting
one's experience of watching. It is a direct way of sharing
with a dancer some evidence of what happened in each of
us as we watched her dance. It can be used for listening
to music, poetry, looking at a painting, etc., just as well. !rs
most important feature is that discussion is not allowed: It
has four parts:
1. Watching
2. Writing-immediately, for 3 minutes, in silence
3. Reading-out loud, in a circle, only what you wrote
4. Collecting and printing what was written
In August 1991, feeling a collective need for
feedback and support in the new dance and perfor-
mance community, I conceived of I.D.E.A. (Internation-
al Dance Exchange, Amsterdam). In October, I collab-
orated with Dutch choreographer Pauline de Groot to
create a platform for such an exchange-monthly
I.D.E.A. meetings at Pauline's studio "DE KOE." On
the Saturday closest to the middle of the month,
I.D.E.A. sponsors an open showing of work and perfor-
mance/audience interaction structures, followed by
informal exchange.
At these meetings, I have been developing a form
called The Fountain, in which spontaneous reflections
are written during a three-minute pause between
dances/performances. These spontaneous writings are
read, without discussion, at the end of the entire show-
ing. The writings are then gathered and published in
the now-bimonthly I.D.E.A LOG, nee I.D.E.A. News-
letter. The Fountain form and its resultant writings
constitute the beginning of an on-going experiment
central to the purpose of I.D.E.A.: To further the explo-
ration of dance as a collective experience in present
time and space, and to create forms through which
glimpses of that experience can be passed.
Over the course of the first I.D.E.A. meetings, I
found that by restricting formal performance feedback
to only reading what was written during the three
minutes between seeing pieces kept the exchange vital,
surprising and full of imagination. To be in communi-
cation with, rather than about, what was seen opened
up a more direct and creative transference between
audience and performer, an exchange in the dimension
dance comes from: the imagination.
The model is conversation: taking each dance as a
statement and responding likewise. The realness of
the moment and our mutual share in creating that
moment is not conditioned or tamed in any way by
calling a dance a "work-in-progress." The moment is
still absolute; the future we envision may never arrive;
the improvements we seek are secondary. In conversa-
tion, someone says to you, "I love you!" You don't
respond by telling them they should focus more on
their pronunciation. You say, "I love you, too." Or you
say something else. So this experiment is a challenge
to us to be in the moment with the performer.
Although my dream is to have a gathering of all
kinds of artists, all kinds of people, the truth remains
that we as an audience for each other are primarily
dancers. And this is, we are, a gold mine of attention
-'-highly developed attention-for each other. As danc-
ers we are skilled as listeners-listening to our sensa-
tions, to the moment we are in, to the transformation
of energy through the moment, to the level of state-
ment that moves you when you see it. It is this won-
derful degree of listening that we bring with us to each
Open Showing. The dances are the tips of the icebergs
of our experience. They are the part we can show.
For complete information on I.D.E.A meetings and I.D.E.A.
LOG, contact Christina Svane, Ruysdaelkade 25b, 1072 AH
Amsterdam. Tel. (020) 662-6827.
